description: Tried the $41.80 special dinner set for Sunday lunch today. Korean cowboy bones were the best followed by fish fillet & tofu claypot. Portions of roast duck in the two bbq items combo plate weren't that good... garlic Chinese broccoli was standard. Came with house soup. Rice per person is $1.50 -- all in all a good neighborhood meal for 3
author: Cathrin P C.

description:
Wanted to try their Hung Tao Yee Fu WonTon....  The wonton were tasty.   Nice mix of meat and shrimp, but the broth was just egg drop with a little bbq pork in it.   No crab, cilantro, etc.

Also saw that they had good reviews for the chow fun.   I ordered dry style black bean beef chow fun, and the kitchen made the gravy style.   Rather than wait for them to remake it, I kept the sup gum chow fun.   The gravy was pretty salty, and kind of greasy.   

Their sui gow dumplings were pretty good.

If I'm in the area, I might stop by again, but wouldn't go out of my way to eat there again.
author: Fun T.

description:
I had a BBQ pork noodle soup when I came here. The place is a sit down restaurant as well as a meat shop. There were tons of customers for their meats, but not as many people were dining in when I went.

The soup I had was pretty bland and I've definitely had better for the same price. There was a ton of BBQ pork and the noodles were cooked well, however, so it was well worth the money. However, the staff are really nice in that the credit card minimum was $20, but they let me use it since I had no cash. 

Thanks!
author: Derek K.

description:
HAIR IN THE STEAMED RICE!!!! SMH!!! 
Place is gross.  I have found hair in the entrees from here but I was dumb enough to go here again:

HAIR IN THE STEAMED RICE!!!! SMH!!! 

HAIR IN THE STEAMED RICE!!!! SMH!!! 
Place is gross.  I have found hair in the entrees from here but I was dumb enough to go here again:

HAIR IN THE STEAMED RICE!!!! SMH!!!
author: Charles B.

description: The best roast duck in San Francisco. I've tried them all and it's better then the one on Noriega and the roast duck ships in Chinatown.
author: Lisa F.

description:
Went here for lunch and had the Roast Duck and Roast Pork 2 item combo. If you specifically request a duck leg it's just $1 more.

The roast duck was decent but it is slightly on the leaner end and they don't have any plum sauce. That being said they do include some soy based sauce in the rice.

The roast pork was acceptable, nice crispy skin on the outside and relatively tender on the inside. The cabbage was a bit over cooked and a little soft.

Overall a decent place but not the best.
author: Tyler T.

description: Super chill family style restaurant. The staff is incredibly nice and because it's super lowkey, you get a lot more attention from the waiter. The food is worth far more than the price - I can probably find the same stuff in the Richmond or even Chinatown for $5-8 more. I'll definitely be coming back for more Peking duck!
author: Calvin H.

description:
It's weird that I haven't reviewed this place because I've been coming here for as long as I've lived in this neighborhood-- 20 years! This has been under different management or ownership at least a couple of times. However, some of the same staff is the same. 

Food is good. That is never really an issue. For the most part, it's been the same over the years. I do notice from my recent visits (usually takeout) that the portions are a little less and/or they skimp on the meat. Super disappointing. Some of my family's favorites: wonton noodle soup, Hong Style combination chow mein, pot stickers. 

This place has loyal patrons, especially because of their roast duck and other BBQ items (bbq pork, roast chicken, etc). I'm teetering between an overall score of 3 and 4, but I'll give them the benefit of the doubt and go with 4.
author: Lani S.

description: Came here on a Saturday morning when it opened. First people in but other customers came. I would come here when I was a child and got the duck noodle soup I haven't been here in years at least a good 10-15. I was craving some duck and egg noodles and this is closest to my house. I was pleasantly surprised to know the wonton duck noodle soup tasted the same. The broth could've been a little more flavorful but it did not disappoint. I remember the bowls being bigger but maybe that's because I'm older now. The service was great. There was some confusion with my friends order but the cook and waitress were kind enough to come back to the table with a plate of fresh noodles and confirm those were the noodles she wanted. Would come again.
author: Chloe C.

description: Passed by the restaurant and had lunch. Order a rice noodle, good taste though a little bit hard to swallow... that's probably why they have it with soup.
author: Patricia L.

description:
It looks like they recently under gone new management - the prices seem to gone up a bit. 

I've been ordering take out since it's super convenient and feel like the service went a bit more downhill. Basically walk in, they ask for your order, make you pay immediately. Also, i believe the owner keeps asking if you're paying in cash since they obviously would prefer not to let you charge. 

I ordered a whole duck, BBQ Pork, and some rice which was just enough to charge on my card since I didn't bring enough cash. He made a big deal and asked, "Can you pay with cash?" Like, I would if I had cash... but again, typical chinese restaurant service.
author: Nancy T.

description: I've been familiar with this restaurant for decades. They've changed hands at least twice during this time, and it's been on and off my go-to list, depending on who is managing it. I've hit it a couple of times in the last few months. The service is courteous, and the food is consistently good. My most recent take-out order included "wet" style beef chow fun, Mapo tofu, bbq spareribs, char siu, and eggplant. All were a hit with the family.
author: Virg Y.

description: The tiny tank of giant carp is thoroughly depressing.
author: Patrick S.

description:
One of the best places for chow fun. The same reason why many people are crazy about using old cast iron pots/pans because it's been seasoned over time, woks are similar. Not many places are able to produce a smokey flavor in their food for this reason. This place got it and it's very apparent in their chow fun.

Their roast pork is also great here. They don't do the whole pig, just the belly. I have no complaints.
author: Andy W.

description: We came here at about 4pm on a Saturday afternoon due to its proximity to Ocean beach where we were heading to. It was a pretty quiet eatery. We ordered the roast duck rice and wanton noodles. Considering it was such a quiet street area that afternoon, we didn't have very high expectations. However, we were pleasantly surprised that the food tasted good. Portions were very generous for the price, which is a rare sight in the city. Service was prompt and adequate.
author: Lindt C.

description:
This place is so far out on Taraval, you can kiss the ocean.  These are the basics I was introduced to at Win's:  soup with black mushroom dumplings, bbq pork, roast duck, gai lan and, of course, a bowl of white rice.  I haven't tried anything else.

The soup is nothing special.  It's a thin broth, if that, but the dumplings are the stars.  Juicy, tender skins hold slivers of crunchy black mushrooms  I haven't seen these elsewhere and they are a treat.

Bbq pork and roast duck are some of the best.  And cheap, too, for a small plateful.

Gai lan just because you need that bright green veggie doused with savory, salty brown oyster sauce.

Add a little rice and you have a simple, delicious and filling meal.
author: Sondra H.

description: Sometimes you just crave greasy food and the Asian girl in me knows where to go when that craving hits.  Win's is your typical Chinese BBQ restaurant where you can get your BBQ items, fried rice, chow fun , peking duck and lots more.  Most of their customers order to-go.  But eating here isn't too bad. Surprisingly, it's clean, even the restrooms. I feel this place is better than Cheung hing.  You can get 2 BBQ items over rice for under 9.00.  That's a pretty good deal in today's world.  I normally get the roast duck and roast pork over rice. It's soo good!.  My friend and i have also good have an order of peking duck to go.  You should eat it quick before the skin of the duck is no longer crispy. The Chow fun with beef and bell pepper is delicious! I normally ask them to use less oil when they make and it always comes out perfect.
author: Belinda C.

description: The food is ok, not a lot of flavor, but the spring rolls are the best I've ever had in my life!!! The spring rolls have amazing flavor and they're freshly made!
author: Melody R.

description: Family Fav for take out. Pots tickers have great taste for a change of fat dumplings at other locations. We order cashew nut chicken, broccoli beef, veggie chow mein, orange broccoli chicken, and snow peas :) cheaper large portions for family is a huge plus...we enjoy their friendliness and the butcher up front reminds me of family..
author: Dianne A.

description: Love the salted fish fried rice, salt & pepper pork,  the roasted duck, & hung siu dao foo.  I haven't been here in a while.  It use to be my go to place.  Pleasantly surprised that they have renovated: new tables & chairs, kitchen revamped (that's what the worker said), and looks cleaner than before.  The food tastes more fresh and better than I remember.  The only thing that tasted better before is the Chinese broccoli.  Will have to frequent this place again.
author: Jeannie C.

description: New owners that are carefully watching standards with better portions. The lame owners from before are finally done! Those cheap bastards!
author: diewney n.

description:
This is my favorite Chinese place. I always get the noodle soup and wontons. I have also had a bunch of their dishes when I ate with my coworkers and it was like a Chinese wedding banquet and all of the dishes were perfect. 

My favorite are the noodle soups, of course, and fried chow mein. Also, their fried shimp rice looks plain but its bursting with flavor - like all of their food.
author: Steph N.

description:
It's litty!

BBQ pork fried rice and honey walnut prawns can give a blind man sight. 

If you havent been here before start living your life. 

Also I dont like spending all my money, So this place is a great deal .
author: AllPodcasts M.

description: Better customer service now! Since new management. Stopped going there for awhile due to old management.
author: roland l.

description:
When I'm here I only order one thing: duck over rice to go. They give it to you in under 5 minutes so you're really in and out. The portion is huge; I typically share this with my boyfriend and we are both left satisfied. Given the chance, I probably could polish this off on my own, but I would probably be too stuffed to move.

The food is honestly greasy and salty, but it's the same taste from when I was a broke and starving college student so it's a nostalgic taste that I don't get tired of. I guess the only difference is that the price and the portions of this dish went up.
author: Hayne P.

description: The food was decent and the prices just fine. Woke up the next morning feeling like I had been stranded in the desert for days... though that isn't atypical for chinese restaurants unfortunately.
author: Courtney Q.

description:
I used to always come here for a cheap bowl of noodle soup or rice porridge before games at Saint Gabriel back in elementary school, but I just happened to wander back here the other day. Things haven't changed too much in 10 years, which is great. Prices are still dirt cheap and the quality is good. 

We opted for the Win's special noodle soup and I "upgraded" to yee mein. Overall, it was good. Served in a nice hot broth with pieces of chicken, shrimp, and squid, I found this to be very filling for $7.95 ($1 extra for the yee mein)...however, I couldn't get over the fact that they cut all the noodles into these tiny pieces (-1 star)! Also ordered a sole fillet porridge which was very hearty. The porridge was infused with slivers of ginger and had a substantial about of fish. It was very satisfying. We also tried their dumplings. They aren't very big, but everything worked together nicely. I also liked that the black fungus didn't overwhelm the entire dumpling like it does in other restaurants.

Definitely a go to for quick and cheap takeout on a busy day!
author: Elaine Y.

description: It is a very traditional Cantonese restaurant. It is on the 40th avenue. There are various kinds of food, such as toss noodle, noodle soup, rice and so on. I ordered beef fried noodles. It tastes just so so.
author: Nancy S.

description: For 18 dollars you take home the whole damn duck. The best damn duck in sf. Juicy tender fatty and flavorful. Even the bones taste good. Not salty at all like the others
author: Gio B.

description:
I'm a fan of Win's. What can I say, I grew up eating their juicy, crispy, duck. I can honestly say that this duck is better than the ones I've had abroad, in Hong Kong. I like the service here too. They try hard, even though it's usually only one waitress and one chef near the window. She always smiles at me and gives me free soup.

Here's what I can vouch for:

Their duck
Their wonton noodles

That's what I give them 5 stars for because that's what they do best here.
author: Jack R.

description:
Win's Restaurant is one of my top finds since I've really started exploring food in SF. It's got the mom and pop shop vibe and serves simple yet delicious tasting dishes for amazingly affordable prices. 

Whenever I come with my friends the big seller is always a nice warm bowl of wonton noodle soup- for less than $4!! Great broth, nice portion of noodles, and freshly made wontons; what a great buy! But wait, you can turn it up a notch- get the wonton noodle soup with a roasted duck combination (get the duck on the side) and it brings the total up to ~$6.80. After a work out or a run around lake merced, this dish is a well earned choice. 

I've been to Win's about 6 times in the past 6 months and have had excellent service with the staff. They mainly speak in cantonese, but coming from someone who doesn't (me), I can vouch that ordering and speaking to them in english doesn't hinder the experience or meal. 

Must try dishes that really hit the spot:

-Wonton noodle soup with Big Dumplings  or roasted duck (both are my faves)
-BBQ pork braised noodles
-Pork spareribs over rice

And with Fall and Winter coming, I will be back very soon for a delicious and well portioned bowl of noodles, wontons and duck!
author: Jon K.

description: This place is not very well kept, it smells of old duck fat as you walk into the restaurant. The service is very fast, the meal taste very homemade. I didn't get the MSG headache or thirst after eating here. The restaurant was empty at 530pm on a Thursday. I don't think I'll come back as I had issues with the cleanliness and smell.
author: Melissa C.

description:
I use to order from this place at least twice a month.  I would always get the Win's Special Pan Fried Noodles with seafood.  OMG.  So good!  It wasn't hard finishing the whole thing by myself.  

Until one day.... I found out what the "special" meant in Win's "special" Pan Fried Noodles- pubic hair  =(  Never again have I returned.  I've searched high and low.  No other restaurant has compared to the price and taste of Win's.  I will not give up.
author: Linda N.

description: This was the most disgusting Chinese food I have EVER had. My boyfriend and I could only take 2 bites of our orders before having to throw them out because they were so gross. He had barbecued pork chow mein and I had chicken fried rice, which are possibly two of the easiest/simplest things to make. How do you screw them up so bad? His noodles weren't cooked, everything was greasy, and I literally think I'm going to puke because of the taste in my mouth.
author: Rebecca J.

description:
My neighborhood restaurant good with BBQ pork, Roast Pork, Boiled Chicken, and Roast Duck. I like to get boiled chicken and roast duck there. Personally, I like this place better than Cheung Hing on Noriega because Cheung Hing's roast duck has too much MSG. I love roast duck and I am not allergic to MSG. However, too much of MSG will get me sick. Also, food overall is on average  and with reasonable price.

I minus 2 stars here because of their service and decoration. Don't get me wrong, their staffs are nice there. However, the owner couples had two times ignored me and I left. I am not very sure if the sauce cost them a lot? Many times I did not get my sweet and sour sauce with my roast duck. I need to ask for it which most of the restaurant will come with the sauce without asking. If I ask for extra sauce, they do not seem like very happy with it. 

Few years ago, I ordered a pan fried noodle 煎麵 on both sided 兩麵王 and ask for red vinegar on the side. They owner debated with me and asked " where are you from, why are you so strange, eat noodles with red vinegar?" I thought they suppose to come with red vinegar without asking. " I was born and raise in Hong Kong and I always see that dish with red vinegar on the side since I have memory ." I answered. Then he asked, " Which part of Hong Kong? What restaurant? I did not see that at all. Maybe it is only your family. " So I answered " Wan Chai, Causeway Bay, Central. Most of the restaurants." I felt kind of weird he debated to a customer for just a little tiny cup of red vinegar but I answered his weird questions, too. Yea... It is a neighborhood restaurant with an owner has his own character。 Learned to enjoy it! 

The other minus one star goes to the decoration. This restaurant looks the same since I was back in High School. Their lighting is always dark. Time to remodel it!
author: Katherine L.

description: Great selection of foods, but we go for the won ton noodles. The noodles are carefully made and have a great snap. The wontons are generous with fillings and great flavor. You can select roast meats and kind of veggies you'd like in your bowl. If you have a bit of appetite, you can even add noodles, always a wise choice.
author: E. W.

description:
I wanted to stop by Sunset's Best Seafood for their fried rock cod dish, but as it turns out, they were closed...on a weekday.  Bummed out, my girlfriend and I decided to try one of the places next door for a change since we always went to the corner store.

I ordered the three meat rice place with roast duck, soy sauce chicken, and BBQ pork and she ordered the wonton noodle soup.  The meat place was just ok and not nearly as good as the ones you'd find on Irving Street.  The wonton soup was totally tasteless and disappointing.  In fact, the free bone soup that came with my rice was better.

This was a total letdown of an experience and I would have much preferred the food at the corner.  The service is a lot better there to boot.  The meat in the window lured us in, but won't fool me again.  I'll pass on this one in the future.

Food: 5/10

Service: 5/10

Price: $

Atmosphere: 5/10
author: Joe M.

description:
I used to eat food from Win's all the time as a kid. With so much fond memories of this place, I had to come eat here again. 

The roast duck from here was just ok. The skin was cooked well and had that distinctive light crisp to it. The meat could've been seasoned a bit better, but it still had a decent flavor. There's a sweetness to it that kind of distracts the typical five spice flavor. It's good enough for Outer Sunset locals, but I think Cheung Hing and Ming Kee are still the reigning champs when it comes to roast duck. 

I did enjoy the noodle soups here. By Hong Kong standards, this place wouldn't be anything special, but it stands out among other Cantonese noodle soup places in the Bay Area. One of the biggest fumbles of wonton noodle soup around here is that the broth is pretty much just watery chicken broth. The broth at Win's wasn't as pungent or aromatic as I'd like it to be, but it did have hints of the dried seafood flavor that added an umami character. The noodles had a good bite to them, and the wontons were seasoned well. They had a good ratio of shrimp, and the seasoning and spices imparted a slight warm fuzzy feeling on my tongue. That's a good sign. I've definitely had better wonton noodle soup, but with its cheap price and decent flavor here, I can see myself coming back for a quick fix. It's better and closer than any place in Chinatown. 

Next time, I have to order the Ngau Jaap (Honeycomb Tripe Stew). This place made me fall in love with tripe as a toddler, and I'd really like to see if they can make it just as good as I remember.
author: Nei N.

description: Neighborhood restaurant only come here if you have to. Portions are small for the soup noodles. The bbq pork and selections are average or below. Many other options in sunset but not in the immediate area.
author: Larry L.

description: they have the best wonton soup..usually super nice service and very fast. i am not a huge fan of chinese food  but this place made me fall in love with it..
author: Karen H.

description:
I have come here many times, 4 out of 5 times it is plain bad!

The wontons used to contain meat now they are very flat and  just of smear of meat.
I love duck, it used to be passable here, but the last three times I had it, it had very little meat and very plain salty. Too bad that they seem to get away with the fact that they have been here for a long time.
author: Charles W.

description:
I've been to this place for years. They used to have BBQ pork and roast duck. However, what makes it worst is the couple owner not the food. The lady at the counter (wife) only take money. She doesn't know jack about the restaurant, even the price on their menu after all these years. The man (husband) doesn't care about anything, except rushing people to place their order. 

Every time I order something, the chef will NEVER cut the amount you ask for. If I order 1LB, they'll cut 1.5LB and make you buy the whole thing. I can't believe the chef so inexperience that cannot cut the right amount you ask for. It happened so many times that I've to tell them I won't buy any if they don't cut the right amount I asked for. 

To add on, here's an experience from my wife that makes my whole family stop buying from them. There's one time my wife ordered TWO noodle soup to go. My wife asked them to separate the soup from the noodle (which is non sense to mix them together when to go but they DID). They charge $0.50 for each extra soup container, which my wife didn't mind even it's non sense. So they charge her $1 extra for TWO noodle soup orders. They only gave her ONE cup of soup for TWO noodle. 

1) How the hell ONE cup of soup is enough for TWO noodle?
2) How the hell they charge $1 for only ONE cup of soup but not $0.50 or give her TWO cups?

Of course, my wife won't let this go. She questioned the owner (husband). They didn't  apologize and even make up an excuse saying ONE cup is enough for TWO noodle!! If that's the case then why they charge for TWO extra container?! They ended up gave her TWO cups of soup, unwillingly. 

Bottomline is, that couple only cares about money and will rip you off into pieces.
author: Jason L.

description:
I used to eat here as my buddy lived closed by. The food was ok but not a place Id go out of my way to eat at. The honey walnut prawns and beef stew was really  good. The fried rice plates and noodles were just average at best.

I stopped going as some of the people here are rude except the lady who collected the money. Service is not very good here. No point in coming back since there's so many other Chinese spots close by.
author: T C.

description:
This is my go to for Wonton noodle soup. It's got amazing fried tofu with soy sauce too.

My family comes here once in a while for our weekend lunch fix and it totally hits the Chinese comfort food spot. Diners are usually Chinese families who are looking for a cheap, decent bite to eat.
author: Steph M.

description:
I've been going to Win's since I could eat solid foods.   Keep in mind that like many Chinese restaurants west of 19th ave in the 'set, Win's is not known for their service. It's a bit grimey too, but if your not afraid of a little grime, your fine.   

As others mention, the duck is something you JUST have to get.  Why else would you go to Win's?  We get the combo pork/duck and beef with bitter melon.  God, I used to hate bitter melon, but after some growing up, my taste buds yearn for that crispy, bitter  vegetable flesh.  Soy Sauce chicken, ginger chicken, and the won-ton soup is good.  One time, I got the soup that was warm.  Ick, I hate warm soup.  Hot Hot Hot!

Anyays, if your looking for a quick fix of good, FAST, unreasonably cheaply priced Chinese in the outer sunset, this CAN be your place!  Mmmmm
author: Cat A.

description: Nothing like 3 bites into your meal and having the owner stop 3 feet from your table and fart and then walk away. 3 bites in and now I have no appetite. Gross. Seriously gross. I can't imagine how gross the kitchen is. I'll never ever come here again. Gross.
author: Ryan K.

description:
This place was so good back in the day that lines would form to buy their roasted pork. Nowadays after the change of ownership, the lines are gone. The quality of the meats has really gone down. 

Even coming here to eat their food is bad. Had their won tons last time I was here. The place was as dirty as most places in Chinatown but the prices weren't as cheap as Chinatown nor did quality match.
author: M C.

description: My bf lives two blocks away from win's and this is our go-to spot for fast and easy take out. Their westlake soup is bomb and is a dish we ALWAYS order. They put so much meat in the soup unlike other places where they hardly give you anything.
author: Linz C.

description:
Local place to pick up roast items. Went at 8PM Tuesday night and there were two ducks left and a smaller piece of roast from a whole pig. The restaurant was not as shabby as I thought. But clearly, they make money on TO GO orders since they have a small TO GO setup table in the front. I will keep that in mind for next time. 

Tried:
*$13.95 Peking Duck (4 of 5) Pretty good. I thought it was good size and nicely roasted. And $13.95 was an acceptable price. The duck was not too fatty or too skinny. 
*Roast Pig (didn't get the price per pound, next time) (2.75 of 5) Pretty bad. I guess I went too late in the night and the roast was out since morning. It looked absolutely great, but it was old. I could only imagine when it was fresh. I will not buy this when I go late at night. Next time, I will go buy it in the afternoon. I think it will be pretty good. I learned my lesson, do not buy roast after 7PM. They only make one or two pigs a day. By 7PM, the roast pig has been out for hours. Too long for me!!!

I will return to try other roast items.

Note: Closed MONDAYS.
author: Janice T.

description:
I have always ordered their roast chicken here because it's very good with crispy skin & moist meat.  Yesterday I had family visiting from SoCal so I wanted them to taste the roast chicken. I called and the owner (lady) answered. 

Me: I would like to order a whole roast chicken.
Owner: Roast chicken? Ok. ready in 10 minutes.
Me: Thank you.

Ten minutes later I went to pick up. I walked up to the lady. She was busy doing the bills and didn't look up ( a sign of attitude...without acknowledging your customers)...I had the courtesy to wait till she's finished ringing up.

Me: Hi, I am here to pick up the roast chicken.
Owner (frowning): roast chicken? we don't have any.
Me: I called and you said it would be ready in 10 minutes.
Owner: I didn't say we have it.
Waiter (who happened to come out from the kitchen & heard us): she checked with the kitchen and we don't have any. You didn't listen carefully.
Me: But the owner said it  would be ready in 10 minutes ! and why couldn't you tell me you had to check with the kitchen first? Instead you told me it would be ready!!!

Owner already bent her head and kept busy with other bills. The man at the chopping board tried to placate me and said I could order something else.

Me: No thank you !

I was and am still mad with their attitude. I will not go there again !!!!
author: agnes f.

description:
- "Bbq" Pork & Duck meat was served cold --ewww
- Wonton Noodle soup was salty and the noodles were like cheap ramen. Straight nasty.
- Service sucked.
- Eating here was like eating at a hole in the wall Chinese spot in China. Wouldn't be surprised if I had ate raccoon meat.

Skip unless there's no other possible option.
author: Joe P.

description: Great food with excellent service! I loved the BBQ pork, fried rice and won ton noodles! Very authentic Chinese food with a variety of choice. Although the shop is a bit dated, the overall experience is adequate! I recommend this restaurant to all of you!
author: Henry L.

description:
My family and I have been coming here for 10+ yrs. Great BBQ items. BBQ pork, roast duck, roast pork, soy sauce chicken and boiled chicken. All is delish. My parents always come here to get BBQ items for lazy nights when they don't feel like cooking, Chinese special occasion dinners and when we bring offerings to the cemetery when visiting our deceased relatives. I've tried so many other dishes they have. I can't name all of them. One of my favorite dish is a special request/not on the menu duck chow fun (dry). 

I'll say service is def better since they change ownership/staff a while back.
author: Jo S.

description:
I only found out about Win's recently when a friend mentioned he had been eating here for many years.  In the 2 months or so I've actually returned several times myself.

I've only ordered their Chinese BBQ items, but it's been very good each time.  On my initial visit I had a bowl of Won Ton and Noodles with BBQ Pork (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hbDkXsC4_ZOt5h04hmPReQ?select=f_N38Wtx-yfeoUOi7hEEug).  There were only five won tons, but these were big and plump and filled with a little ground pork and lots of firm shrimp.  The noodles stayed firm and chewy even while sitting in the hot broth.  A generous portion of thick sliced BBQ pork sat on top of the noodles; these were lightly glazed, tender pieces of pork.  

On a more recent visit I had the BBQ Pork and Roast Duck over rice (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hbDkXsC4_ZOt5h04hmPReQ?select=mS9pKO8j_AsecMsLAKjxyA).  The duck was very good in flavor, but take a close look at the duck skin; you might want to remove the skin when it isn't plucked clean.  That's usually not the fault of the restaurant but the poultry supplier.  Again, lots of BBQ pork and the usual boiled lettuce comes on the side unless you request otherwise.

Overall it is very good Chinese comfort food.  The service is friendly, and if you order BBQ items your food is ready right away.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description: I was craving roasted duck over egg noodles and decided to come here. They gave a generous portion of duck and a healthy sized portion of noodles. I've gotten the egg noodles with vegetables before, I think it's just cabbage, but the bowl and amount of noodles was significantly more than the other ones, assuming to compensate for no meat. Haven't tried anything else, but this is definitely where I'm going from now on
author: Jessica W.

description:
I used to come here in college and came back a few days ago for dinner.

Got here around 7 and got seated right away
. Ordered half a roast duck was good
Tong choy was excellent 
And a salted fish tofu clay pot. Was ok 

Tis place is consistent with their roast foods the other stuff on the menu is hit or miss.

I would be back if I was in the neighborhood.
author: DOM d.

description: After driving by on our way out to the beach, we decided to stop in on our way home to pick up a peking duck!  We love duck but have never ordered it like this to go and eat at home.  For the price and quality it was a good move and the side of sautéed veggies was excellent quality.
author: e w.

description: We came here for lunch and for the roast duck. The duck seemed like any other duck, but it was good. I got minced beef rice and it was just okay. My dad got roast duck and rice noodle soup. My mom got roast duck and egg porridge. That was really good. I hadn't had that before. The waitress was really nice. The interior isn't nice, just a typical Chinese restaurant in SF.
author: Denise C.

description:
Whenever I have a craving for won tons, I usually come here. 

~Pros~

- It's cheap!

- Very decent won ton for the price.

- Their BBQ meats (pork, roast duck, etc.) are good and lean. No one wants a fatty BBQ meat!!!

~Cons~

- Sometimes, it can get a little crowded on the weekend, therefore making parking a bit harder.

- There is a $15 or $20 minimum for a credit charge

Short & simple review! If you have never tried Win's , check it out next time you crave won tons or just plain ol' Chinese food.
author: Selina L.

description:
This review is for the quality of food and dine-in service. 
Customer service is fine -average but I thought our waitresses dirty finger nails needs to be cleaned. 
I used to think this place was great despite the place being not so clean. The quality of food has definitely declined. I ordered the general chicken, boyfriend ordered sweet and sour shrimp, roasted duck and sauteed spinach. The duck was pretty blah. Not much meat and was a small serving. The general chicken was heavily breaded as was the sweet and sour shrimp. I was highly disappointed because it was literally like being served fried flour drenched in sweet and sour sauce. The boyfriend was like "this is how it is at restaurants". Yeah, Chinese restaurants. The chicken inside was the size of a large cashew. The shrimp in side the large layer of deep fried flour was so tiny and tasteless. I prefer not to come back here ever again. This goes for many Chinese restaurants (Chinese are cheap and will do anything to save a penny even if it costs your health!! so beware...and be wise). O___o 
Total of the bill was around $30 something for 4 dishes. I thought it was expensive for the crap ass food we were served.
author: Carmen L.

description:
Known throughout the years of serving some of the best roast duck in the city, Win's has lowered the standard of their food and service to being one of my bottom Chinese restaurants in the city.

Lets start with the bowl of siu ap won ton mein (roast duck wonton noodles) what this place is known for.  I placed my order and after what seemed like an eternal 15 minutes I had to ask the waitress for a status.  I can understand if the place is packed, orders get lost but my table was one of four tables occupied.  The waitress finally brings my order and this is where the downward spiral begins.

I took a sip of the broth from the bowl of won ton noodles.  Luke warm!!  I sifted around to see how many won tons amongst the noodles and found only three which is about three under what they normally served in the past.  My duck came on the side per my request.  At first glance I can see clearly the coagulated fat around the meat.  Nasty!!  I take a bite and as suspected the duck is cold as if it were sitting for hours.  I immediately flag down the waitress to advise her of the duck situation, I did not even bother with the soup and won ton for fear of liquid payback.  She advises she will get me some hot duck and walks to the back which I found odd since they just brought up three fresh ducks to the front window.  

The waitress returns and places a small plate of steaming hot duck.  The same duck they served me before but freshly zapped in the microwave!!!  I am thinking Are you kidding me???  I immediately refuse the duck and ask for her to take the entire order back and take it off the bill because I am not eating it.  She has the nerve to say I need to pay for the noodles and won ton, she will take off $2 for the duck.  I advised her that they are violating food safety standards and I will call the health department if they do not take the entire order off the bill.  She finally relents and took it off the bill.  All I can say is on a sunny day those rays hit those ducks in the window for God knows how long.  Don't run the risk of being served room temperature cold duck, avoid this place entirely!!
author: Grubnoisseur Y.

description: This is an outrage, can't even get a simple glass of water unless you eat there. Low quality food anyways.
author: Kenny N.

description:
I tried Win's the other day, and it was not too bad. It was also not too good. 

The BBQ was standout - delicious, good flavor quality, decent portions. The BBQ pork was top notch, and I'd definitely get it again. The Peking Duck was relatively reasonable in it's pricing, and while a bit greasy (as duck tends to be), it had an excellent flavor profile. I also dig that they toss in steamed buns, plum sauce and some rinds to go with it.

I was less impressed with the house chow mein, which I had with Hong Kong noodles. The flavor was kind of similar and undifferentiated throughout the dish - meaning that the scallops and the shrimp and the chicken and the pork all had a similar flavor. Not a lot of veggies beyond bok choy.

I've  yet to try the other Chinese joints on the block, so I don't have a great comparison point in the neighborhood, but compared to some of the Chinese food throughout the city - this place is a solid, but unremarkable place.
author: Jonathan M.

description:
Went there and got a roast duck, when I went home I have noticed that there were fewer pieces than it should be. Almost like they took some pieces.

I will definitely stand next to them next time (instead of go over to Walgreens opposite to shop) while they chop up the duck.

This has never happened before, so I will give them another chance.
author: Christy T.

description: Utterly Disgusting,It is horrible,The food is low quality and in low quantity,and yet it is expensive,try next door sunset seafood,it is in bigger quantity and tastes better
author: Philip T.

description:
This place is definitely on my speed dial for Chinese food takeout. I must say that I order the same dishes all the time. I can't get over their roasted bbq duck over rice, wonton soup with green onions, mongolian beef and my favorite, their fried wontons.
Unfortunately, they lack customer service skills, and they seemed a bit cold. 
I don't take it personally because perhaps it's just the way they operate. Nevertheless they treat everybody the same. So don't be surprise if they ask you, "What do you want?" or give you that look,"hurry up!" 
Also, I don't recommend eating in because the place looks depressing. But if you're all about the food, and you don't mind how the place looks, then pull yourself a chair. I highly recommend the fried wontons and roasted bbq duck TO GO!
author: Po S.

description: I usually order takeout when I'm at a friends house. I usually order a salt and pepper chicken, dry pan noodles, or porriage etc. Its reasonable and fast and great service. Their duck is really good as well and short ribs. If your looking for quick bite I would come here. Their food is great and the portions are huggeeeee!
author: Tiffany K.

description:
My parents know all about these hole in the wall restaurants dotted along the Sunset area, which brought us to Win's Restaurant.

My mother even called ahead to make sure the food would be ready so we could grub before our flight.

* Roast duck - I like roast duck, especially when it's fatty and tasty and there's a lot of skin still hanging on.  I like their version.  Obviously, this is what they are known for and their most popular dish, for good reason.  It also came with roast pork, but I was too focused on the duck to really care about the pork.  But it's supposed to be really good here. 

* Fried rice with egg whites, pine nuts, and black fungus - Fried rice is the last thing I ever order, but this variation is so good!  It's not often you see pinenuts in Chinese cooking, so that already makes it different and unique.  I'd definitely go back and have it again.

* Fried rice with preserved pickles - There was other stuff going on in here too, but I can hardly remember because I enjoyed the other fried rice dish.  The Husband really liked this dish though and he ate it all up and took the leftovers to work the next day!  

* Dumplings - We ordered two kinds, and they were both good.  Fresh and with lots of shrimp.

We also got complimentary soup to start, but we had so much food going on already so we couldn't really enjoy the house soup.

They had a good mix of diners, Chinese and non-Asians alike.  Families dominated this place on a Sunday night, so it's definitely a locals place.

3.5 stars.
author: Teri C.

description:
Solid food, lots of seating, extremely fast, and cheap. That pretty much sums up Win's. While I found their garlic eggplant to be okay, I thought their wonton noodles and duck to be great. If you're looking for a cheap meal, come here. It's a Win-Win's situation (sorry, I couldn't help myself).

My tummy gives Win's Restaurant...4 Stars!
author: Allan L.

description: Sizzling rice soup - good! Roasted duck - really good! Manila clams with Chinese wine - food for the soul. Great tasting food to fulfill your Chinese food cravings.
author: Miki S.

description:
After some renovations, Win's is a place our team goes back to time and time again for the roast duck, wonton soup, beef claypots, and pan-fried noodles.  Other highlights include beef satay chow foon, general tzo's chicken, and BBQ combination plates.  

Service is fast, friendly and helpful.  The decor is simple, somewhat clean, and that of a typical Chinese restaurant with roasted birds hanging  above a rotisserie grill out front.  Parking is tough on the street, but it's possible to find around the neighborhood.
author: Jenny L.

description:
I'm not picky, but it's supposed to have dried fish and shrimp roe in the ingredients of the wonton soup, but they don't.  So the wonton soup is kinda tasteless. 

The Oyster with Roast Pork and Tofu in Clay Pot is yummy.   BUT, be aware that the female in the cashier is very dishonest when comes to the pricing.  The price on the menu was $7.95 and the price tag stuck on the box was the same; however, when the server asked this female  whether charging me $7.95, she said NO. she ended up charging me $8.75.  Even my mother-in-law had the same experience saying that she always overcharges.   But the male owner is OK.
author: Brielle K.

description:
Came here for takeout.  I ordered the tomato beef chow mein (thick noodles) and the beef chow fun.  The flavors are very good and authentic Chinese.  

The amount of the tomato beef chow mein was only half of the take out container.  Love the tomato sauce.  They gave a little more of the chow fun though.  Thank goodness.  The prices for each is $6.95.  Still a good deal.  The wait was too long.  It took about 1/2 hour for my orders to be made.  Service was too slow..

While waiting for my orders, the man who works up in front of the restaurant cooking noodles somewhat coughed into some wonton noodles.   The owner at the register didn't seem like she cared for my business.
author: J W.

description:
We came here after trap shooting at Lake Merced with my bf and his coworkers. One of his coworkers live by here, so he suggested this place.

It reminds me of greasy Chinese-American food. It's not the best but I guess it's comfort food. This is not the cleanest place but the food is cheap here. The service is fast.
author: Melanie B.

description:
I came here yesterday night with two of my friends. We arrived at the restaurant at 9:33pm, knowing that it closes at 10pm. We were desperate to find a place that was opened on a Saturday night since my two friends didn't have dinner yet. Our originally plan was to go to 8 Immortals but it closed at 930, so we opted for this place. It wasn't exactly the best looking restaurant from the outside, but the inside was decent. The decor is old-fashioned with minimal decor hung on the walls. It also has a television at one end of the wall.

So as we walked through the door, the waitress greeted us with a hello, quickly setted our table with tableware, and gave us the menu to look over. She paced back and forth which made me nervous although I wasn't going to order anything. She even came to our table TWICE to ask if we were ready to order - all within three minutes or so. However, she was really polite and told us to take our time. (It was understandable since they were already getting ready to close the restaurant down for the night.) After some quick deliberation (clearly under the pressure), my two friends settled on Seafood & Pineapple w/ Egg White Fried Rice and Sauteed Mixed Fresh Vegetables with rice. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hbDkXsC4_ZOt5h04hmPReQ?userid=NLgTfZz_ITzmV6KiO-mGIg Both dishes were around $7.

The portions were huge! Each dish was able to feed at least two people. However, the food was unable to be finished within the fifteen minute time frame that we had left in the restaurant, so we asked for the food to be boxed. The waitress nicely boxed it up for my two friends with a smile on her face. I checked my cell phone, and it read: 10:09pm. We paid and said "thank you" multiple times. The waitress thanked us in return and wished us a happy new year.

Friendly staff, quick service, and decent prices for big portions. Four stars well deserved.
author: Annie S.

description:
FOOD
Very tasty.  My wife loved the won ton noodle.  I particularly enjoyed the barbeque pork and the roast duck.

SERVICE
Not bad.  Par for the course for SF Chinese restaurants.

PRICE
Inexpensive.  Our bill averaged out to about $10 per person.
author: Subrosa I.

description:
This place is ok, not the best chinese food around, but not the worst. It's definitely cheap and decent food. Nothing too special about this place. It's average. That's all I can say.

They do accept credit cards which is a plus for chinese resturants, but the only download is that there is a minimum charge of $20 (I might have got the amount wrong). So if you don't have any cash and want something cheap from this place, tough luck =(

Friendly waiters and waitress. Good place.
author: Christina L.

description:
-I'd rather eat panda express-
That pretty much sums up my review. I found the food very bland and not worth the price. The chowmein tasted like a microwaveable dinner, and the beef was no better than the meat served at malls. The only reason I went to Win's was because Hong's (directly next door) was closed and the owner was on vacation.

I will not return to Win's at any time in the future. I HIGHLY recommend Hong's. Hong's is next door, and has far superior food at comparable prices.
author: Graham U.

description:
This is my moms go-to-place to order Chinese take out whenever she feels lazy and doesn't want to cook. But today I ordered Spicy & Salty Sole filet over rice which is basically just fried fish over rice. It is a simple dish but good comfort food for me. 

However, my friend ordered the Seafood over Hong Kong Style Fried Noodles. He was hoping to get a lot of seafood but there was only about 3 shrimp and 1 scallop with a bunch of filler veggies. We expected more from Win's seeing that we order from them quite often. (Check the pics to see what I'm talkin about)

The workers are always very friendly and you receive your food very quickly. This place has a warm home-y feeling to it, it's nice. The food is relatively cheap too. My spicy and salty fish over rice was only about $6. $6 for a rice plate lunch ain't that bad; plus, I was pretty full. 

Nice people, non expensive Chinese food, and a wide array of selections.
author: Benson T.

description:
I normally get things to go from here since it isn't too far from my house but one day my mom and I decided to eat here for lunch.

Arrived about ten minutes til 11am, their normal opening time.  Luckily they let us in and sit down and order.

I got the beef with tofu with rice ($6.50) and my mom got salted fish fried rice and we got fried won tons for appetizers.  The food came out pretty quickly and the portions and prices were great.  My mom had leftovers for a few days.

It maybe isn't the cleanest restaurant (table was a bit sticky) but good prices and good portions.

I enjoy their bbq pork and won ton soup and congee.
author: Noreen F.

description:
Came here on Sunday afternoon.  Good comfort food. - old fashion chow mein, chow fun, noodle soup.  Watched the other customers who ordered basic cantonese cooking items.

Nice homely place
author: Bill L.

description:
This was a find.  From the outside, the place looks unassuming and not particularly distinctive on a block with two other Chinese restaurants.  The tables are sticky and I'm not that attracted to places with ducks hanging in the window.  But they serve several kinds of congee, so I had to give it a try.

I had the pork and preserved egg congee ($4.50) and it's the best one I've had on Taraval St.  The consistency was a little watery (I prefer Eight Immortals for consistency; I think EI cooks it longer because the rice has broken down more) but for flavor, Win's is better.  Win's puts fresh ginger in the congee (so does EI), but Win's pork tastes better.  It's shredded and definitely marinated in soy sauce.  Very nice.  The broth is flavorful too.  You can also get the crispy Chinese fried donut (not the best I had but Chinese fried donuts are always greasy) for an additional charge and extra preserved egg for $1.  Extra preserved egg - I love places that offer this option. I think this place has the best jook in the Sunset/Parkside.

The won tons are filled with pork and shrimp.  I prefer my won tons to have more pork (so that they're juicier) but these are good.  The big dumplings are better than the won tons because they also have Chinese chives and black fungus (adds a crunchy texture).  

I came on Sunday for lunch and every table was occupied...the place was bustling.  People were waiting for tables and many pick up orders up front.  Seemed like everyone there was Chinese.  I like the front area where they chop the duck (there was a constant chopping sound) and cook the dumplings.  The duck looked very good from a distance and not too fatty.  

Service is brusque and efficient.  She asks, how many (in your party) and what do you want, and that's the extent of the conversation.  They have specials posted and the prices are reasonable (but not dirt cheap).  I do wonder why a homemade Chinese tamale is $4.95 though.  That seems high but maybe you get more than one.

They take credit cards but there's a $20 minimum.  They have large and small tables.  I wouldn't bring anyone who is squeamish about eating at a place that's not spotlessly clean but I would bring other Chinese people :-)
author: Lolia S.

description:
My boyfriend really wants me to stop writing negative reviews of Chinese restaurants in the city because he thinks that sooner or later I'll be hunted down and hacked into bits by angry Chinese mafioso.

Yeah.  So...I'll just say that their wontons are actually pretty good.  

But that long strip of sticky fly paper hanging from the ceiling- really not doing it's job.  They may want to invest in a bug light or something.
author: Joanne G.

description:
My sister and I went here for an easy Chinese new year dinner... (Hey I already cooked for 11 on Saturday, what makes you think I could deal with more!)

Anyway... for 25 bucks we had their 6-course dinner meal...no, not the family style on the front with the Americanized dishes...the one glued to the back of their menu, with more chinese-style items.

Fatt choy (seaweed that resembles hair) with lotus root soup--nice flavor, but obviously sitting too long in the lotus root.

Steamed chicken and roasted duck--fatty, moist, delicious, and just hard to resist

Braised tofu with fish fillets--good sauce, too much breading on the fish though

Steamed gai lan, with oyster sauce--yum.  I'd go back for more of this

Shredded beef with stir-fried peppered onions--good flavor, just that the meat was soaking in baking powder too long--yeah, we could tell, as it melted onto our tongues, and not in the good way

Last item was dessert--red bean soup, yum...not too watery, and full of bean flavor.

We also ordered their special of the day--pork dumplings--soft and chewy on the inside, crisp on the outside, and a nice gingery flavor.  

Service = loud people in the front by the BBQ meats, and just as loud from the kitchen in the back.  So, they're friendly, but expect real 'Chinese' people (curt, efficient, and just loud)...and at least they try to speak English too.  (Then again, I try to use my limited chinese but...)

Decor = bright room with patches of busted out fluorescents, dark furniture, and somewhat clean but lots of foot traffic in and out of the kitchen, so it's a bit dirty on the floors.

$20 minimum for the credit cards.
author: Fannie S.

description:
Win's is a no-frills Chinese restaurant with cheap, good food. It's the kind of place that looks kinda dirty inside, but you keep coming back because it's cheap, good, and in the neighborhood. There's a constant row of double parked cars outside the restaurant because this is the kind of place where Chinese families stop to pick up takeout for dinner. I know that's what my family does, and we end up eating Win's takeout way too often. The roast duck and roast pork are excellent, as is the steamed chicken, but sometimes you get shafted with the janky, non meaty parts of the bird or pig. Don't take it personally; they've even done that to my mom, who's a regular and orders in Chinese.

The congee, wonton noodles, crispy chow mein, and beef tofu rice are among my favorite things to order. And everything's so cheap too! $5-$6 for a rice plate or wonton and I'm good to go for dinner, and sometimes even with leftovers for lunch. Part of my regular rotation of Sunset restaurants on the cheap.
author: Jessie C.

description: Yelp help us find this restaurant, other wise we probably would not have stopped. The roast duck was crisp, juicy and only lightly seasoned. Wanton soup was good and the special potstickers were not special. The setting is very mom and pop. Sitting in the front window cooking is a delight to watch. Service is good.
author: Terry M.

description:
I used to love this place for pretty much everything, especially the roast duck and wonton noodles!

One day my mom and I came to get a roast duck for lunch, and when we got home, there was no duck breast! okay, so I don't know what the hell they would do with a frking duck breast, but they didn't give it to us. Ducks don't have much meat aside the breast. So we were pissed as fuck.

We went back, and my mom started bitching at the lady behind the register. I don't know if she was the owner or anything; but they did what you would expect them to do. They said that that's bullshit and they would never do something like that. Fuck your shit!

Check your food before you leave!
author: Erica A.

description:
my family and i have lived by this restaurant since i was little and i think their pork fried rice is the best. the best i may have ever had. For 6 bucks too, what a deal!~ not too shabby. im not a big fan of rice and actually not usually able to eat very much in one sitting, but i can eat a full to-go box. their wonton soup is really good as well. i love the people that work there. even though i'm sure i look like any other asian girl that comes there to eat, the lady at the register, when ringing me up the other day, said 'Oh, its you!' and smiled.  

i recommend this place to anyone in the area. it may not be the most romantic or clean place around, but it makes up for it in favor, taste, and comfort.
author: Cicely T.

description:
I came to Win's many times and my favorite entrees here are still their barbecue spare ribs, wonton soup, barbecue pork fried rice, and their soy sauce chicken. Their duck is good too but cannot compare with Cheung Hings. However, their soy sauce chicken and barbecue spare ribs in my opinion, are better than Cheung Hings. Their soy sauce chicken has a very smooth texture to it and the sauce is great. Their spare ribs are glazed with honey and it's delicious. The last time I came here, I tried their roasted duck with dried wonton noodle and ordered their barbecue pork fried rice. Sad to say, their bbq pork fried rice did not meet the standard of the previous bbq pork fried rice. It still had flavor but it was missing a lot of bbq pork meat so it was like eating salted fried rice with pieces of eggs and green onions. Even the roasted duck with plain fried wonton noodle tasted better than the fried rice that I usually order here.

Anyway, they get the meals ready really quickly esp for to go which only takes about 10 minutes. I would recommend getting food to go if you're hungry and in a rush. The service is ok. I would rate this place 3.5 stars if I could because they have good Chinese food.
author: Monica C.

description: Disclaimer: This place probably uses a crap-load of MSG!  Well, if I am going to eat it/eat out, might as well be on the best duck noodle soup in town.  This even beats the not-so-coherent late nights out in C-Town, where the bowl of duck noodle soup seems like an insta-cure.  Really, what more can you ask for...$6 din din that fills you up and satisfies the taste buds.  Hubby likes the won ton noodle soup with bbq pork, and he says it rivals his other fav place: Won Ton Noodle House.  Given that I favor Win's, I win that battle (sorry had to put the pun in...I couldn't resist).  Time for hubby to get our pick-up order.
author: Steph W.

description: The Best Duck, Barbecue Pork and Wonton Noodle Soup in Town.
author: Walter T.

description:
My hubby and I call this place the "Duck Nazis" and they have every right to be one -- because their ducks are so flakkin' delicious!!! (for you BSG fans out there)  It's amazing - they have not only the meatiest ducks but tastiest.  Skin is a little crunchy and the ducks are not too fat.  It's really worth the $10 and the drive out to the Outer Avenues.

Their other dishes are good too, and cheap.  When you're too lazy to cook, just order a couple of their dishes for less than $10 and then you're done.   They are very busy in their to-go business so best to call in first.  Otherwise, you will have to wait as long as 1/2 hr during busy nights.  

Closed on Mondays.

**********
Revised 6/4/07

They have NEW OWNERS!!  Taste is still relatively the same although the duck now has a lot of fat.  Not sure if it is a change in sourcing.  Need a little more time to figure out if it is for better or for worse.
author: Jannie Q.

description: Greasy over-cooked food, with a generally greasy feel to the tables also.  If you want poorly cooked Chinese food, this is the place for you.   Simple dishes like eggs rolls arrive in pile of grease.    Can't imagine why they have been in business for so long, maybe it is because they were the only game in the neighborhood for a long time.
author: Axa M.

description:
Man, it took a long time to drive to this place. I was hoping that given its relative proximity to China that the BBQ meat would be good as most of these Yelp reviews suggest. Sadly, again it would have made more sense to head the other direction and go to R&G. Aren't there any hole in the walls around where I can get a good BBQ rice plate??

The duck was dry-ish and lacked the intense flavour that it should have. The sauce was also lame. Honestly, the duck at 99 Ranch in Daly City is better. The char siu was actually pretty tasty, but I find it tasty at most places and it was a little too fatty for more liking.

On the plus side the service was good and efficient. 

If this place were walking distance from my apartment I would consider going back, but given that I feel like I need to pack my passport when I head out this far, I don't think I will be returning.
author: Jeremy H.

description:
Theres not much I can say about this place.
1 - it's cheap
2 - it's good
3 - you can't get any better for the price

Really, if you're in the mood for roast duck come here. It'll be cheap and you'll be satisfied.
author: Eddie C.

description:
I gave this place five star based on the food and only the food that I suggest that you get. This will be on my list of 5 star food at 1 star places. 

The best roast duck 
The best roast pig 
The noodles specifically the rice noodles.

That's it! Do not get creative and order any other things from this restaurant. All of the other stuff is just blah. This place is one of those off main stream bbq pork/roast duck/ roast pig places in the sunset district. This is outer sunset and everybody from outer sunset knows about this place. The decor, the service, the cleanliness are not all there, so do not expect it to be an all around well lit, well kept great restaurant.   It is a Chinese owned restaurant with predominately Chinese speaking waitresses.  Speaking is Chinese to them is a plus but is not necessary.

Remember............you are here for the food only.
author: jason g.

description:
This is the perfect place for "I refuse to get ready days". 
Yes, they serve traditional chinese food
Yes, they have take out (roast duck, chicken, the whole shabang).
and ..
No, it isn't the fanciest resturaunt with various wall decorations .. 

BUTTT

their food is absolutely delicious and cheap. Along with that, they give you big portions and the servers are really friendly. When dining in, it comes with complimentary soup. Good golly, I could go for some walnut shrimp and salty fish fried rice right now.
author: Brenda C.

description:
Bottomline :  There's always the pros and cons. 

Pros: *  Very cheap with a decent quantity even if you're a heavy eater ($5-8 / person)
* Wait time is generally low (5-10 mins tops)
* If you come in a group and if they have the supply, you'll receive free soup and it's pretty good (applies to lunch time)
* Service / Waitress is friendly and nice 

Cons:  * Overall the place gives off a vibe that it can be a little more hygenic
* The food here can be a bit oily depending on what you order / or heavy in fat
(By this I mean, roast duck or stew beef - can be high fat content sometimes when you prefer to see a bit more meat)
* The quality of the food highly varies between dishes - I would only recommend the standard BBQ related material or stew beef and a few other dishes. 
I do not recommend unorthodox orders like the curries or the Americanized dishes.
author: Ken N.

description: Pretty cheap food but the roast pork and duck was pretty unappetizing. It came with white rice and some old cabbage. I won't be going here again.
author: Laura C.

description: ordered for a pick up, WoW! did I ever feel ripped off. Caveat Emptor, let me explain! i ordered 2 roast duck & bbq pork over rice & when /i got home, i was looking at how bad the integerity of the owner is. They gave me what appeared to be old left over bbq from the front rack, stuff that wasn't sold & either frozen or refrigerated for later use, fresh cut bbq pork should not be dark in color & stale tasting! writing this instead of calling is cause my cantonese is not fluent & just wanted to give everyone heads up when taking out!. the duck was alittle better, not sure if it was as old as the bbq pork. i hope owner gets wind of this as i will not order from them again, until! in addition, the portions are small, but price is big..........
author: david c.

description:
Hands down, best roast duck in the City!  I get this over white rice with the roasted pork with crispy skin, not to be confused with BBQ pork a.k.a. "char-shiuu".  The soy sauce chicken goes with the duck well too.  For the uninitiated, you will find these dishes under "Barbeque Items" as "combo barbeque items and rice".  You can even order three items if you want.  

Sometimes i get the duck with wonton and noodles.  Just be careful, as the heat from the soup tends to "cook" the duck, giving it this gamey taste ruining the duck!  I usually, fish the duck out of the soup as soon as it comes to my table.  The rice won't do this, because it's not hot enough.  Duck is fatty and boney.  It gets a little messy, because you will use a combination of your chopsticks/fork and fingers.  

The place is kind of "greasy spoon".  Cleanliness could be a lot better.  Service is like what you get at most Chinese restaurants in my experience (and I'm Chinese!).  Don't be offended, it's mainly cultural, not personal.  The dining room is sticky and kind of dirty.  It's cold in the winter too!  So consider ordering your food to take out.  

Despite this, the duck here is still THE BEST!  I've had some of the other dishes, which are average.   The duck is the main reason I come here and give it five stars!  Closed mondays--bummer!  On Mondays, I'll go to Cheung Hing on Noriega.
author: Stephen F.

description: Mediocre at best.  I was not a fan of the cabbage & ginger soup; just a flavor I guess I am not use to, the roast duck well good, was greasy and yet tender with five spices; other places can do it better.  The spicy sole fillet has a light badder and jalapenos; not true salt & pepper; and the seafood yee mein is good, but fishy.  I do not think I will be coming back; also, the service was just okay; a bit indifferent and cold.  I will have to try Sunset's Best a couple doors down.
author: Brian S.

description:
Win's is your basic Chinese charcuterie, i.e., a place that sells roasted meats and the dishes that you'd combine with it, such as noodles.

I've found it to be tasty and filling. I particularly like the seaweed, duck, noodle combination. 

After reading some of the reviews here, I wonder if we went to the same restaurant. One reviewer objected to cold roasted duck but doesn't seem to realize that when you roast the duck and hang it up, it gets cold. It's cooked already and has been eaten that way by billions of people for centuries. 

Another person wrote about being charged for the house soup. House soup is always free at Win's, so I have to attribute the writer's problem to a misunderstanding. 

Basically, this is a solid place for roasted meats and noodles, with some creative items in addition.
author: Greg T.

description:
Is 3:30 pm the new 12 noon on NoriA$ea and Outer Sunset District? Or is it because nipples tend to harden on a dreary typical San Francisco Sunday afternoon in October where it was easily 20 degrees F colder than in the Peninsula Bay Area, causing an intense arousal where the cure is a lust for hot red meat?

Something must have went down yesterday, as Old Mandarin Islamic and Win's (Wing Fai Siu Lap Meen Ga in Canto Chinese, or "Forever Glorious Roasties & Noodle Haus") were packed to the gills where it smelled of meat and restaurant atmosphere everywhere and possibly the softening of nipples from the gush of warmth into the body from good hot food. Or everyone had the same idea to eat during that cold time of day. OMI in particular where EVERY table was having hot pot,  as if the restaurant had some afternoon tea di$count $pecial, the "tea" being numbing hot spicy hot pot broth for dipping or shabuing (swish, mofo, swish!) their lamb n' beef into.

Cheung Hing Noriega, the roa$tie$ hau$ of choice amongst the people, had no customers, no line, yet no parking space for miles on end. This drove me over to Win's to give them a shot, just to see what the fuss was all about.

For some reason the Wins meat master (butcher) was absent for about 5 minutes. After what seemed like an eternity he finally emerged and got my order.

I bought half a roast duck and half a soy sauce chicken to go and while they were a bit cheaper than Cheung Hing, they weren't quite as good. The duck's sauce/marination reminded me of New China Station San Jose, where I could taste all the strange herbal like medicinal mix, all drowned in soy sauce. The chicken was decent but nothing to write home about otherwise.

Lots of specials on the wall that I didn't pay too much attention to, and overall Win's looks like your typical old neighborhood joint, much like the other places on Taraval.

So yeah, is 3 pm the new noon for bites? Or are more $ini$ter force$ at work that drove A$N peep$ to eat and snack?

1) A$N$
2) Cheap afternoon tea $pecial$, or just cheap eats in general
3) Fog & Freezing Cold (nipples pointing at high noon, or westward three on the sun dial)
4) All of the above

I'm bettin' on #4, coz SF isn't turning into a late night snacking culture like Taiwan!
author: Ken K.

description:
Chinese Deli's are often misunderstood. At first glance, the ducks hanging upside don't seem very appealing. Looking past the window display, Win's restaurant serve delicious bbq spare ribs.

 Tender meat marries perfectly with the tangy sauce. Their poached chicken lacks flavor. I would suggest them to first brine (soak meat in water and salt) over night. For a great side dish, the orange octopus has great chewy texture. 

For thrill seekers, their duck tongue has great texture, similar to tendon. Stealing the show, the roasted pork features meat with a pungent spice. The skin crackles with one bite. Another good dish to try are the chicken wings in soy sauce, a great snack especially during a great NBA finals game.

 I have found that different deli's around the city highlight a certain dish and at Win's, the spare ribs are a must try.
author: Rayfil W.

description:
Win's is a winner!

I picked up lunch from here today since one of my jobsites is down the street. I was looking for a restaurant that was supposed to have a good crab in black bean sauce. I think this is the place. It's been a few years. 

So I got the duck over rice plate. It's my new fascination....seeing how much chocolate and greasy foods I can eat before an acne breakout. 

My duck wasn't very meaty and it was cold. But it was a nice surprise to find cabbage with it. It's my other new fascination...seeing how long I can go without veggies before I get Scurvy. 

Their health inspection report score was 93. Also the owner is changing per the notice on the door. 

I noticed on the menu that they also serve ostrich. I guess that's good to know if I'm every dying for some ostrich. 

I'll go back and try the duck again. Maybe tomorrow and I can add Gout to the Scurvy and acne for a hat trick. Wish me luck!
author: Kevo M.

description:
The food isn't bad, don't get me wrong. But the new owner can seriously go to hell. One way ticket, VIP, no waiting in line. 

I've had so many confrontations with him that it's become routine. 

First confrontation. I went to go buy a roast duck to-go. It was under 10 bucks. I had no cash on me so I was going to use the plastic. The guy sitting behind the cashier said minimum was $10. I explained to him how I was in a hurry, had no time to go to the ATM and that it was only 25 cents short of the minimum. He replied by asking me "It's only $9.75. You don't have money? It's pretty cheap you know." (In Cantonese.) He then told me to just simply buy more stuff and then he'll let me use plastic. I told him before, that the owner always let us irregardless. He snapped back by saying "Go find the old owner then, we're the new owners!" So I looked him straight in the eye and left. 

I dread it everytime my parents tell me to get pick up from here. Second time, I ordered a noodle soup for my dad. Usually, places would separate the noodles and the soup in 2 different containers. This guy just puts the noodles in a container and then ladles the soup in. Not only does this create really soggy noodles, but there isnt enough soup as the sheer volume of the noodles leaves no room for soup, so when you finally pour it in a bowl, you have an island of noodles and barely any soup. 

I complained to him about this, asking him to put soup in another container. He goes "I already put soup in here." I asked him, can you just give me a container of soup? There isn't really enough in there. He replies by saying, sure, the container will cost 50 cents and then $2.50 or a bowl of soup to-go. I was seriously almost about to smash his face into the boiling water. 

I'm done with this bullshit review. 5 stars for the old Win's, and the new Win's can go to hell. The owner, his family, and their families. Hum ga chahns.
author: Derrick L.

description: While Cheung Hing is probably preferable for the hard-core duck junkie, a trip to the quiet, sit-down, refreshingly non-dingy Win's yields a much more comforting experience as Outer Sunset Chinese dives go.  Indeed, after a hard week, nothing says "food is love" like taking a boneless slice of peking duck (with extra skin, of course), tucking it into a steamed bun, lightly dipping it in plum sauce and popping it in your mouth.  I get misty-eyed just thinking about it.  Besides the duck, the menu goes on for miles, complete with lots of prix fixe "family dinners", and the specials on the wall are quite unique-sounding.  It can't *all* be that good, but if Yelp could lead me to a few more dishes on par with the duck, you'd have yourself a 5-star place all the way.
author: Wes M.

description:
This is your quintessential hole in the wall Chinese place - some place you go for *normal* comfort food.  If you like the typical ABC dishes, salt pepper pork, honey walnut shrimps, etc - this place is 'ok', portion size are decent.

If you like your Won Tons, congee, and Roast Pork, THIS is the place to go.  I'll come here just for the Roast pork.  I don't know how they make it, but it's the best dead pork I've eaten.  BBQ Pork - not so hot, roast duck - ok if you like them fat.
author: Ed F.

description:
i love the mongolian beef from this place though we have noticed there must be a different cook on different nights because it does vary night to night - though always good sometimes better. Good food, good prices! 
Oh and try the duck!! YUM!
author: Candy H.

description: Hey! This place is great! Just around the corner and the food is always great! Come in, eat up, or take out, and call it a night!
author: Jack L.

description:
Did you just say steamed chicken? Yes, indeed you did. Music to this healthy yelper's ears, even when coming from a Chinese BBQ joint. And let me tell you, the smallest size, a half portion, is about enough chicken to feed me for a week. I could have gone with half of a half of a half and still had enough for its intended purpose - topping on a spinach salad. Little does Win's know, they are feeding me and someone as a replate. Everyone wins.

This much positive feedback usually means four stars, but I had to subtract one for the chef (Win?) spitting right in front of me. Not on the food, but into a trash can. Gross. But that still was a lot of steamed chicken.
author: Jason B.

description:
We were lucky and went on a late Sunday afternoon, otherwise parking would've been really difficult as it is commonly in this particular area. This place is also a very tiny whole in the wall with very minimal & tight seating. My chair was against the table behind me! That was a bit awkward..

We were a party of 5 so we ordered 2 plates of 2 bbq items (duck & bbq pork and duck & crackling/roasted pork), seafood porridge w/a side of kidneys & picked vegetables, korean style buffalo wings, fried tofu, one bowl of dumpling & egg noodle, and a bowl of wonton & egg noodle.

The bbq items were ok. I would rather save my money and go down the street to Cheung Hing. The "korean style buffalo wings" were just fried wings w/honey drizzled and some sesame seeds on top. It was WAY too sweet! I had one wing w/out the sauce and it was a lot better. The soups and porridge were very simple, nothing extraordinary. The fried tofu wasn't very crispy either. More on the soggy side. Basically the only dish I really liked was the kidney & picked vegetables. Nothing really stuck out as great to me.
author: Kitty K.

description:
I've been nursing a huge craving for roast duck over rice lately (hmmm...maybe my intake of grease and salt isn't meeting the government's Recommended Daily Allowance) and thoughts of Win's keep popping up.  Sure, Win's does other dishes well enough and they also have a great deli but as a bunch of other reviewers state, Win's really is all about the Duck.

I used to come here after work to satisfy my roast duck cravings but I've since moved out of the city.  Now, sitting an hour and a half away, I'd actually consider making a drive out to 41st and Taraval just for a simple plate of their roast duck and rice (and perhaps add a couple whole ducks boxed up to go in order to stave off further cravings).

Win's is cheap, the food is good and I can't think of anything else to add that hasn't already been written about this fine hole in th' wall.
author: Man of Leisure M.

description:
I'm a Chinese girl and I better damn well know Chinese food, no matter how Americanized I've become! 

4.5 stars. 

I just LOOOOOOOOOOOOOVE their beef chow fun!! It was tough, I couldn't decide if I like the chow fun from JoJo's or from Win's. I think I like Win's a little more. 

I love roasted duck and I've had my share of bad experiences with roasted duck. The roasted duck at some places have a funky after-taste. This place got great roasted duck. Make sure you try it out!
author: Nance W.

description:
This place is delicious! I love their duck. It's a tad bit more expensive, but very worth it. It's not as oily as some other places. 

The old mean lady is not there anymore, so the staff are definitely more friendly and the atmosphere is a lot better. I really didn't like her  because she would yell at the staff while we were eating..not cool. So if she is reading this then, THANK YOU FOR SELLING THE RESTAURANT.

Everything is good..watch out for the vegetable dishes. We ordered one, and it was small and totally expensive. (We ordered off the menu-not a good idea).
author: Vanessa W.

description:
Quick basic food.  Nothing special or fancy but tasty.

had the Tomato beef chow mein and a number of different Won ton noodle soups.  Street parking with no meters.
author: Ray Y.

description:
Wins. Wins.

Totally agree eith euge l. From mama at the register to her son in the kitchen this place is authentic chinese food without the hurried pace and abrupt service. They've been around, oh like... forever and continues to serve up food with excellent consistency.  My favorites: West Lake soup, Beef Stew and chicken chow fun with gravy. mmmmmmmmm
author: Stephanie I.

description:
Supports my conviction that duck in the window == worth a stop.  Better yet, worth a drive from anywhere else in the city.

Come here for wonton noodle at lunch, leave with a couple takeout dishes for dinner.  That's what my very Chinese parents (in town visiting) did yesterday, and today, and probably again tomorrow while I'm at work.  Following this formula, lunch and dinner for three was just about $30 - can't beat that value.
author: Amy H.

description:
I've been coming here for years, an almost weekly visit to get my salt and msg fix. Yup, this place is not for the health-conscious types, but if you want to indulge a bit, you will be rewarded with some very tasty food. As individual tastes can vary, reviews will vary accordingly. And as choice of dishes goes, it can also vary, thus, ratings will swing accordingly as well. 

Here are my personal favorites:
