Roast Duck, hands-down the best this side of the city...If the duck is cold and you order half to a whole duck, they will oil blanch it to get the skin crispy and hot again before serving to you...ahhh! It's as close to being in duck-heaven as you can get.

Roast Pork, hands-down the best anywhere other than the one I had in L.A. They use a center-cut (don't know if that's the technical term) but the perfect section of meat has just the right proportions of skin, fat and meat. They bake the specially cut sections throughout the day. If you're lucky to get it right from the oven....mmmm, mmmm, mmmmmmmm. Don't come too late. The roast pork sells out readily.

BBQ pork, hands-down the best anywhere--they use the cut of meat that is more expensive...tender with just the right amount of fat. As I said, this place is not for the health-conscious. Lean pork is usually too dry for my taste. Not these...lean plus fat equals moist succulent meat. And if you're so lucky to get one in which the fat is sorta al dente, like between fat and cartilage...Oh my, yummmm. 

If you're a fan of duck feet, don't forget to order some, especially the claypot version served with black mushrooms.

Also, do not walk away without trying the hung tao yee wonton...it's an old chinatown dish that very few restaurants make this dish anymore. We like a variation with westlake beef soup base for the hung tao yee tun.

Their salt & pepper chicken wings is one of the best! Salt & pepper fish is yummy as well, as is the calamari.

If you like egg and shrimp over rice noodle (watt dan hah fun), be adventurous and try their satay version. 

And since I'm a regular, I often order variations of their dishes to suit my taste as well as averting boredom from eating the same dishes.

The people who own Win's are very nice people, once you get past their serious side. It's tough running a small mom & pops business. And believe me, there are "customers" who come in and try to take advantage of them or try to freeload. I've seen it happen time and time again.

And speaking of cleanliness...they may not spit shine the silverware or wipe the tables with the utmost care, but I see them putting the cleaned utensils in boiled hot water to sanitize them, hand dry each utensil and chopsticks, and then at the end of the day, piling the chairs up and scrubbing the floors clean of the day's foot traffic. And so, this is the time I make my leave with leftovers in hand.

One more thing, the house soup is complimentary...if you think they charge for it, something went askew in the translation/interpretation.
author: Lil D.

description:
Meh. Nothing outstanding, but nothing horrible about the food here.  We got the 6-course meal and I was a bit surprised by the smallness of the dishes as I was expecting typical Chinese banquet portions.  For only $24 though (and only two eaters), it's a good amount of food.

The gai lan was nice and crisp.  The chicken and duck were good (not great) but fatty.  The chicken's ginger condiment made me a bit homesick; it smelled like what my dad makes. The rest of the food: meh. I liked their red bean dessert, not overly sweet.

Although it may not be for everyone, I liked the atmosphere. It's a small restaurant and they cut up the ducks and chickens right by the front window. Some will probably find it loud and annoying, but it made me feel right at home.  They were also doing a lot of takeout, so there's a lot of Chinese flying back and forth in the front.   (I was slightly annoyed by the other patrons though. One couple kept adding dishes when they saw other people's which confused the wait staff. Another table had a kid who kept making comments about the decor, the people, the Chinese flying around--blegh.)
author: Yan E.

description:
An after school stand by. Win's has been holding it down with cheap, belly-sustaining entrees for a long time. Evidence: the owner still sits on her stool in front and calculates your order on a notepad. No calculators in sight. 

They are famous for their duck, but I don't have to tell you: you will be able to discern that from the many ducks hanging in the window and the many many framed reviews on the wall that tell you that the duck is the ish. Spicy garlic chicken and won ton soups are also highlights. 

Warning: The boss lady a.k.a. speedy human calculator has little tolerance for customers who cannot order in Cantonese. Pointing to the menu item seems to help little because she then frustratedly squints at the menu and guesses which entree you wanted. However, if you can get over the language barrier (bring a friend!) it's totally worth it.
author: Kari M.

description:
Win's offered great sized portion rice plates at extremely reasonable prices.  I always get the combo rice plate with roast duck and roast pork.  They give a huge amount of both, with a side of steamed cabbage and a mountain of rice that I can never finish. Ask for extra duck sauce on the side for make it a little juciy-ier.  

I would pass on Win's Potstickers, which they claim are their speciality.  They seem to have a bit too much ginger in them.  And when I told them it tasted that way, and wanted to send it back, they responded with "Well that's how we make it."  Thats fine if that's how you make it, but at least let me take it off my bill.  In the end they did take it off, but they didn't have to respond the way that they did.  

Overall, come here for the combo rice plates which are served quickly and at a reasonable price, but given that this is a Chinese restaurant, please don't expect much on their level of service.
author: Cass J.

description:
This place rocks, and it's been around for close to 20 years.  I used to live across the street when I was a kid (41st & Taraval - represent!), and between the ages of 10 and 15, I picked up a shitload of food here.  They have ducks hanging in the window and really good chow fun.  If you're jonesin' for jook (a Chinese rice porridge), they serve that here in the am and give you the 'Chinese doughnut to dip into it with.  Yum!

Definitely one of the better Chinese food joints in the Outer Sunset/Parkside area.  I'd eat there all the time if I still lived there.

I' m giving them 4 stars because the middle-aged Chinese woman  (she's probably kind of old now, and possibly dead!) who ran the place and sat at the cash register used to be a little brusque with me whenever I went to pick up food.
author: Karen F.

description:
Best darn  "food for the buck" in SF..

This place is a REAL sleeper.  Like Cinderella who does not have time to "pretty up"....  It is the Ugly Betty of the Outer Sunset, and I am gilng back tonite,for the second time this week..

$25 fixed price meal feeds THREE, easily..... 

But:  it is not the volume, but the quality, that will call you back..jb
author: John B.

description: Been coming to Win's for years.  Experienced two owners and the food have been consistently tasty and substantial throughout the years.  This restaurant has always been a great place to take family & friends for quick cheap Chinese eats.
author: David L.

description:
Pros: Entrees are reasonably priced and they give you a lot of it. If you can't decide go with a rice plate, not the fried rice but the (item) over rice. Can't go wrong with that. =D

Cons: A little too greasy for my taste sometimes. Avoid ordering Broccoli Beef and Tomato Beef Chow Mein. You can totally feel the MSG after your meal.

Service is alright and the people speak some okay-ish English.
author: Jason C. J.

description:
You know when people say "This is the spot!"?  Win's is THE spot.  I've been to Win's about 4 times now and still can't get past the set menu or "pre fixe" for you gastro-technical people out there.  $22 for the two person set gets you soup, Chinese broccoli, their "oh my shit this is outta control" roast duck and chicken, clay pot fish and tofu with nappa cabbage, pepper beef, and dessert.  Tonight, we ordered oysters with green onion and ginger in addition to our "usual" and it was the kaboom!  

Icing this wonderful gem of a sunset chinese restaurant is the friendly personal service.  Not the "Hurry up what do you want, hurry up and eat, now hurry up, pay and get out" service I've come to expect in many a Chinese restaurant in the City.  For example, after eating until we both were ready to explode, the owner made sure I had enough boxes to even bring the rice home if I wanted (without asking).  She also made sure I packed in every bit of cabbage from the clay pot, even though I already felt like a total glutton bringing home enough food to feed 3 more people.  Yeah, its good.  Yeah, its really good.  They know it, and they don't make you feel like they're doing you the favor when you eat there.  They're grateful, and years and years of regulars are grateful too.  ALOHA!
author: Barry A.

description:
I live three blocks away, so I would really like to love this place, or at least love to like it.

They were supposed to have this amazing won ton soup, of which I am a big fan. When I ordered it, I was very disappointed. The broth was way too salty. 

The fried won tons are actually very good, which earned them that third star.

There are just too many good, cheap, Chinese restaurants in this town to tolerate mediocrity.
author: Mike M.

description: The prices aren't bad, but the food itself is really not that great... If you happen to be in the area and need a quick and filling meal for a decent price, go for it; if not, I would keep my options open...
author: Andrew P.

description:
Grew up in this neighborhood and saw the progressions of the growth of the business.  The original owner recently, well not that recent anymore, sold it to someone else.  

In any case, it was great to have a "WonTon House" close to home.  Wonton Noodle Soup is essential to an Asian Man's diet.  Gotta have it once in a while and they certainly fit the bill.  Their BBQ Items are pretty good too.  Probably not on Cheung Hing's Level but pretty good nonetheless.  

They also have this tamale that no other place has that I like to eat once in a while.  In fact, I haven't ate it so long, I may just make a trip out there sooner rather than later......
author: Mark W.

description:
This is a good place for Wonton Noodle Soup and Roast Duck if you're in the area and need a quick bite to eat.  The duck here usually has a nice thin layer of fat under the skin which is critical for moist duck.  I really dislike the the duck at places like Chueng Hing where the fat content seems to overwhelm the flesh.

However, like most small chinese restaurants, the place does need a little cleaning.  I wish they would take advantage of commercial restaurant cleaning services.

The other dishes on the menu (a la carte/family style) is about three stars.  It's nothing to truely rave about.

All-in-all this is a good place for food if you live in the area and don't want to travel too far for chinese food.

Three stars only cause of the roast duck.
author: Curt L.

description: My Chinese mother orders food to go from here and she used to bring me here for Wonton noodle soup. That means the place must be cheap, and good! and it's both. All their pork is good and their main dishes are good too. It's no fuss homey chinese food, nothing fancy.
author: Karen T.

description:
If you have been visiting this place for more than 2 years, you should know what this place was like 2 years ago. There were plenty of reasons to come here 2 years ago and there is absolutely no reason to come here now.

For the same food, good to Norjeg2 Chenug Hing!

What a disappointment....
author: Andy L.

description: If your hungry and you want a cheap meal in the Sunset you will get a lot of bang for your buck at Win's. Some may question the lack of ambiance or the scary guy chopping up roast duck or barbecued pork in the front but I have yet to get food poisoning from this place. Not much of a review but cheap + food can equal food poisoning. I have been ordering here for over four years and never had a problem.
author: Eric H.

description:
I like this deli for the stuff hanging in the window. They have good pork and fowl here. I also appreciate that the deli man chops the pieces evenly and clean through the bone so that you don't choke on tiny bits when you bite into your duck and chicken. I almost choked to death once when I was a kid because of someone's poor butcher skills; my mom started chopping her own stuff after that.

Saltwater chicken with ginger-scallion dip was my absolute favorite thing to eat growing up and I still like to take down a good chicken whenever I can. The chicken here isn't rough and overcooked like at some places and I love that they're not stingy with the ginger-scallion dip because I slather my chicken in it and also mix some into my rice. The roast duck is very tasty too and not excessively fatty. I also like the noodles here but the chow fun is just okay. My sister and I ordered seafood chow fun one night and there was very little seafood and veggies. I think it only cost $6 something so there probably wasn't much more to expect. I'd come out here just for the deli items. Actually, I think I will tomorrow...
author: Queenie C.

description:
This is the only place that I guarantee that the wonton noodle soups are a never fail and always delicious choice. I can't get over how the soup base can make all the difference...there's just enough flavoring in it that it's not overkilled by soy sauce!

Love love the noodles, they're usually ramen style. The rice plates are also a good hit for lunch. I haven't eaten dinner here..but since this place has only a few tables, it's not a really big place.

Call in and make a take-out, they are fast! I never had to wait longer than 10 minutes for my food.
author: Pauline L.

description:
Sorry to say... I gotta diss on Win's. Their food isn't that good and the few times I've gotten takeout rice plates from them, it's been like 99% rice and not really much of the food. It was mad cheap, but I would like less of the rice. There are so many other places in the Sunset with better takeout for a buck more. 

Win's is suppose to be a duck and roast pork place, but I've had it and it wasn't that good. The pork was tough and had too much fat. The duck was not meaty enough. Why don't people just go to Cheung Hing... it's like a mile away and has WAY BETTER food. There is a reason this place never has a line out the door and Cheung Hing does. 

In short... barely decent food, but why even come here for that. Skip Win's and check out other places in the Sunset
author: Arick R.

description:
I haven't bought anything from here except roast duck. They have really good roast duck. I used to buy it from Noriega between 30th and 31st Ave. across from Safeway. My friend suggested Win's. And I thought "why not?"

I prefer Win's even though they are a bit more expensive. But I like it because the oil is in a tiny container on the side. The place on Noriega puts it with the duck. Yuck!!!!

I know roast duck is very fatty. I try to take off the skin and pull the fat off and toss it. I sometimes even take a paper towel to soak up the oil from the duck.

Win's Resturant is a winner by far.

Service here is ok, but the food is awesome. It can be pretty difficult to get some good chinese food in the sunset/parkside, so this place is set in the perfect location. I've tried many of the other chinese food around that area and none has deserved a second trial except Win's. It's quite unique how the resturant is set up. If you order BBQ plates or wonton noodle they'll make it in the front of the store, but like chow mein and fried rice comes from the back. Kinda feels like eatting in China town.
author: David M.

description:
Be careful, this place has a floor slicker than the local jiffy lube.  I've felt more stable while trying to walk across thin ice.  

Yes it isn't the cleanest place, but what decent Chinese food is?  They have a little BBQ station at the front, elevated above the greasy floor that the common people have to slide around in.  And from what I could tell from eating the BBQ pork, these people know their BBQ.  I'll definitely be back to try the duck and order the BBQ pork again.  For $5.50 you get a sizable plate of pork, which is not too fat laden and is actually tender and flavorful, a great combination.

The other two dishes I had were the special spicy pot stickers, which were strangely not spicy at all, but were huge and flavorful nonetheless.  Also had the tomato beef chow mein, which was a loser, not recommended at all.  Finally the Ye mein was quite good and I would definitely order it again.
author: Stephen H.

description:
I would give this place five full stars but to be honest I only come here for a couple of things and have not yet tried many of their food menu items so I don;t really know just yet. 
BUT...i can say that their roast duck low mein and roast duck ho fun are mouth wateringly delicious! I come here for my roast duck a good once a week to treat myself. Yeah, it's THAT good. 
Can't say too much about service or decor...it's a chinese resturant afterall. You go there for good food. Nuff said.
author: nancy l.

description:
Our late night dinner spot every tuesday night.. great hole in the wall chinese restaurant... although i am accompanied by people who speak chinese and know the good food, not the regular chinese food people usually get.. we get the dishes that are not on the menu or the ones that are in chinese and people like me cant read them... good solid consistent food!!  
Bad note:  floors are very slippery... never fails. I just have learned to be very careful as i walk across their floor
author: Shelley N.

description:
I luv Win's.  Outstanding cheap Chinese food.  Chow mein, low mein, chow fun, roast pork with bean cake, roast duck, won ton noodles, etc.

If you want a cheap Chinese meal at a greasy spoon, hole in the wall ghetto restaurant, try Win's.
author: Raider J.

description: Just had lunch here with a coworker.  This place is famous for their roast duck and I ordered the quarter $6 plate to share.  I ordered the wet egg and beef over rice and my coworker ordered Mongolian pork.  At lunch, you get free house soup.  The soup is the standard dried bok choi, carrot, and pork bone soup.  It tasted good.  The roast duck came out in about 2 minutes and we were able to eat this while waiting for the rice plates to be cooked.  The duck was moist and flavorful.  Slightly crisp skin and good meat.  It was cooked more such that more fat was rendered out, but not dried out.  The duck is highly recommended here.  My wet egg and beef over rice plate was good as expected like at other restaurants in San Francisco.  The serving was ok-generous.  Price was $5.50 for the rice plate, pretty reasonable as most other restaurants are starting to reach $7 for the same dish.  The beef was tender, and the egg was mixed with a lot of corn starch to make a thick egg-drop soup consistency.  The lady waiting tables was very nice and efficient.  I enjoyed her deliberate enunciation when repeating the dishes we ordered.  Very nice woman.  The atmosphere was bright, but the L-train passes every 15 minutes which thunders by.  I enjoy this place and has been one of my regular locations for lunch for many years.  I highly recommend the food and service here.
author: Ed K.

description:
Great chinese food in my neighborhood. Love the wonton soup dishes and the duck is pretty good since its one of the only roasted duck and chinese bbq places in the Taravel side neighborhood. Since there are now new owners I say the food taste just the same and I think the service is better. Yeah the waiters and waitress speak limited english, but they're friendly and patient.  I think the old owners especially the lady owner who always was at the cashier was scary. 
The fried chicken wings are yummy !
author: Sabrina L.

description: Very good roast duck and hot and sour soup here.  Another plus is that this restaurant opens until 10am, one hour later than most similar restaurant serving HK-style barbecue.
author: H K.

description: Review for Wonton Soup to Go.  For $6.00, five lonely wontons in a plastic container.  Broth sprinkled with green onions was in a separate container.  In summary, very bland pathetic looking orders of Wonton Soup to Go.  There are many better options in the Sunset.
author: Lucky L.

description:
i live 4 houses away from wins. 

it has won me.

its food that tastes good, and doesn't cost a lot. What more could you want?
author: Danny H.

description: Ive gone here for 20 years because it was always decent and cheap but I dont go much anymore because the service sucks and the staff is surly and very unfriendly.What really got me was I went in for take out and they wanted to charge me 25 cents for an extra litle plastic container of chili sauce...I could not believe it!!
author: james m.

description: The place is not fancy but the food is great tasting. I ordered the seafood chow mien & veggie rolls and it was delicious & portions were large. To top if off, prices were very inexpensive. Will definitely go back again!
author: Selma R.

description: This place is known for really good wonton soup and roast duck and I agree.  They are pretty consistent with the quality and portions.  The restaurant does look pretty old and the floor is sometimes slippery.  This place is good if you want good traditional wonton soup and duck.
author: JACOB L.

description: I think I've been eating here since I was 12 and nine years later it is my favorite places to grab roast duck. I feel that the restaurant lost a bit of its great taste from the past (before it burned down) but other than that definitely the roast duck and BBQ pork are the bomb. I would give this place a 3.75 star of out 4 if I were to be a bit picky.
author: Jonathan C.

description: This is the best BBQ take out place in the Sunset!  I always come here for their BBQ roast duck, roast pork, BBQ pork, steam chicken, occassionally their squids.  All are tasty good.  Always long line for take out BBQ food esp dinner time weekend or weekdays.  I appreciate their food and they opened this place for many years and hope they stay open for a long time.  I appreciate the convenient of having this type of Cantonese food in the neighborhood.  Once in a while, want to have a good won ton noodles soup, just go to Wins, and I will dine in because eat in won ton noodles soup taste better then take out ---maybe is the soup and noodles can get soggy when take home.  Their service is not too bad to me, people may thing they are rude but just their style of communication to me.  Overall, I am still their fan!  Thanks Wins!
author: Kitty G.

description:
GYEAAAAA!

Now we're talking.  Win's, another SF landmark for those of us who lived in the ghettos of lower sunset.  If my memory serves me right, Win's is the number one spot in the set to get roast duck (we are now going to refer to Sunset as the set because I'm starting to relive my days as an adolescent teen).  You order half a duck with steamed rice and it comes with steamed cabbage in a light oyster sauce.  How many fucking chinese restaurants in LOS ANGELES do that ?  Sam fricken WOO definitely doesn't and they're goddamn roast duck is close to fricken 20 bucks! Ok whew, I need to calm down before this review turns into a socal chinese restaurant bashing review...

Anyway if you're ever in the "set" make sure you stop by here for some bomb ass roast duck.  You won't be disappointed!
author: Hung T.

description: Gotta try the Chinese roast pork and won ton noodle!
author: Porkchop S.

description: This is my favorite after marathon spot, I've been here once each year for three years and each time right after I finished the marathon run. What better way to satisfy my huge appetite with greasy chinese =) The shrimp wonton soup is pretty good here. The duck is ok, not the best in sunset but pretty tasty still. This place also sells duck to go. Duck, wonton soup and guy lan is what I look forward to at the end of my race. Lookin forward to next year...
author: Susan L.

description: The food is great. It comes quickly. Portions are generous. A *tad* on the pricier side for what the restaurant is, but it's good authentic Chinese food.
author: D T.

description: A lot of times, I just don't feel like fighting the crowds on noriega and irving, so I walk down the block to Win's and never leave unsatisfied. The staff is very prompt and friendly which is always something more than expected at real old school chinese restaurants..lol.  For some reason, i just love how they prepare their roasted pork. they serve the best part of the pig too, always. Their roasted duck is juicy and full of flavor. I always get that with ginger and green onion lo mein (braised noodles). Broth could use a little kick, but good nonetheless. They post unique specials on the walls too: pinenut, egg white, fried rice...or something interesting. Those are a hit or miss. I just stick to the basics here and enjoy my usuals.
author: Brian C.

description: Love their bbq.  The roast duck and roast pork are the best.  Especially the roast pork, the skin is crisp, nice flavor, not too salty not too bland, and they only use the belly part, which is best cuz it's not all lean meat.   The ginger scallion chicken is yummy too, but i think it's a lttle over cooked.   Fast serivce, close to home, my favorite place for togo in sunset.
author: Tadaa T.

description:
wins by far is the best chinese food i, as a non chinese can easily get. i know there are others out there, but wins is super nonchinese friendly, easy take out service, and the food? oh good lord, some of the best roast duck around. they pack in every serving this duck sauce liquid stuff that makes every bite an mouthgasmic experience. 

their noodles and wontons second to none. excellent. excellent.
author: Euge L.

description: yum.  we ordered so much... egg rolls, BBQ platter (pork, chicken, ribs), kung pao beef (not on the menu btw), pork fried rice, braised noodles with wontons.  And ate every last bit, except for the noodles which we found lacking in flavour and so totally not worth it.   Everything else was super good - me and reno fought over the last wonton (he won.) Cinzia was being crabby and insisted she didn't like anything, but I saw her sneaking bites of pork fried rice when she thought nobody was looking.  Reno's  "I done" was betrayed by him sniping Jack's bbq chicken over and over.  Jack's quick hand commanded most of the pork fried rice and all the bbq reno couldn't reach.  So there we all were, stealing eachothers food and loving it.
author: Meg W.

description: Cheap Chinese Food! But, that's about the only thing going for it. I was extremely disappointed in my experience. Came here with my team after practice because this is one of their favorite places to go. Unfortunately, I've had better. The skin on the potstickers was really thick - not a sign of a good Chinese restaurant. The walnuts served with the Walnut Prawns tasted slightly stale. Overall greasy food which did not taste really fresh. I would be very reluctant to return when there are much better Chinese restaurants in San Francisco.
author: Lisa M.

description:
hello ... flavor??? where are you??? when the new owner comes in, he stands right on top of his cooks and watches them like a hawk making sure they don't add anything to the dishes. sure the economy is tight, you could downsize your dishes, streamline you ingredient list, fiddle with the prices but when quality suffers ... i've had steamed rice with more taste than the last dish i've had there recently.

all that said, win's is still a cheap eat and timing your visit may still earn you a good meal, fast and fulfilling. make sure you take some1 with you who speaks cantonese when you go.
author: marvin l.

description: I have been faithful to Win's for over 10 years. It was THE neighborhood go-to spot for everything roasted (duck, chicken, pork) and of course, the crunchy shrimp Pan Fried Noodles. It's unfortunate that it has since been transferred to a new owner because frankly, it's like losing a member of the family - to leprosy. This place now sadly serves cold Pan Fried Noodles with half the shrimp, half the bok choy, and twice as much baby cockroaches.  Horrified but still hopeful, I turned to the won ton noodle soup to find a slightly larger cockroach's legs (count them- 2) floating atop the dark bland broth.  Dismayed but not yet defeated, I finally turned my chopsticks to the plate of cold roast duck, to find, not more cockroaches, but lots and lots of duck follicle hairs.  Needless to say I paid my bill and got up to go outside and vomit.
author: K N.

description: very good "siu yeah!" (i.e. roasted stuff) roast duck, BBQ pork. and wonderful wonton noodles. the kitchen also cranks out unique offerings of chow mein, chow fun, and even serves sauteed ostrich. Ostrich meat tastes like beef but is lower in cholesterol. recently remodeled the dining area which makes dining there a nicer experience.
author: Jeff W.

description: ROAST DUCK! Enough said! Been going here ever since a was a little kid. Best duck in the bay area! Prices are super cheap, I  guarantee you'll leave win's satisfied and full.
author: Lex S.

description: Well it sounds like everyone really likes this place and it was recommended to me by my Chinese co-worker.  We got take-out from Win's last night and it was totally awful.  There was no chicken in the "General Tsau's Chicken" (it was all breaded and fried fat) and the tofu/veggie dish had a weird taste and odor.  The potstickers, however, were delicious.  I guess we didn't order the right stuff, but I don't really like duck and it's too bad the other stuff wasn't good.
author: Sarah B.

description: Win's is a great place for feel good Chinese food...jook (rice soup), won ton soup, you know the stuff mom used to make. Even the stuff mom used to bring home...roast pork, char sui, and roast duck. All three are fantastic! Don't go in expecting a fine dining experience, it's a hole in the wall Chinese restaurant, but you defiantly get much more than you pay for.
author: jamie p.

description: Found this place by typing in "roast duck" on yelp...and it was perfect.  They have these family dinner plans for $10 (min. 2 people) that included an egg roll, wonton soup, duck, chicken and brocoli, and shrimp fried rice.  All were excellent, the service was nice (which goes against the rule of good chinese restaurants), they didn't bully us out when we were done (which goes against good chinese restaurant rule #2), and there was more than enough food for left-overs.
author: Mark D.

description:
We've had take out from here so many times but I kept forgetting to review it while the food was fresh on my mind and in my belly. But tonight, everything was so good, I had to bust out the keyboard as soon as I had wolfed down a plate-and-a-half full of food. We've never actually sat down in the restaurant to eat. It's just always been much more fun to get the food to go and inhale it in the privacy of our own home along. I had no idea there were new owners, but I don't think the quality has changed.

Tonight, we had:
*chicken salad - perfectly seasoned, albeit a teensy bit soggy (which really doesn't matter when you eat it as fast as I do), but sooo flavorful. Be sure not to make the mistake my funny hubby made the first time we ordered this:  do NOT order "chinese" chicken salad. It's a chinese restaurant so it's just chicken salad! (Wasn't that on an episode of Friends??)
*broccoli beef - the beef was juicy and tender, the broccoli still crisp and soaked in enough of the sauce to burst in your mouth when you bite into the little tree
*bbq pork - We think this is definitely one of their best dishes. It's always tender, and made with lean pork Lots of other places we've tried bbq at have used fatty meat. Win's pork is meaty, baby.
*veggie chow mein - not as many veggies this time as it usually has (bok choy, broccoli, carrots, celery, mushrooms, etc.) but I love their chow mein noodles so to me, the more noodles the better! These are not the skinny mein noodles but the thicker, chewier noodles.
*combo fried rice - the only ordinary dish, but still yummy
All that food and yep - just $33!

In the past, we've also had their chicken wings (very garlicy but yummy, especially when it's still fresh and still crispy), hot & sour soup (delish - not too hot that it burns your taste buds off so you can't even taste anything else), and kung pao chicken and cashew chicken (ditto). You just can't go wrong with Win's for the taste and the price!
author: Teri T.

description:
This place is one of the better restaurants in the Outer Sunset, for sure.  Nothing fancy, but the food is good and cheap, and the service is decent.  I felt like I was actually over at a friend's house when I ate here as opposed to an actual restaurant (which is a good thing, I guess).

We ordered an oyster claypot, Chinese broccoli, black bean sauce clams, and rice.  It was enough to feed three people, plus leftovers, and we got out for around $25.  The included desert was an almond jello that wasn't too bad.

Not a place to drive to if you're coming from far out, but if you're in the area, hit it up.
author: Ryan T.

description: can I say the best roast duck in sf?? the best! and I used to live in chinatown. Most of the time the roast duck in loaded with a thick layer of fat under the skin. The duck at Win's is usually so lean that it's almost healthy to eat (ok, I am just justifying my pigging out)  It is a casual inexpensive chinese restaurant. Get a bowl of roast duck noodles if you are ever in the neighborhood
author: Jenny W.

description: If you're looking for some great chinese roasted duck, look no further! The duck is very meaty, and moist. The prices are very reasonable.
author: Gilbert D.

description: I love their wonton soup! Quite recently, I've tried their regular menu items and so far those have turned out to be quite good too! The prices are relatively cheap and for the price quite tasty.
author: Julie L.

description: New owners.  Same good pork.  'cept ask for the pork sauce.  Them new owners are lil stingy with da sauce!
author: Tim L.

description: I come here when i need to buy cha sew, duck , or chicken for my mom because it's s close to my house. Theres prices are really cheap too.But it gets crowded on special chinese days because all the moms want the chicken or duck to bai sun. It may look alittle dirty, but the food is good , so dont be afraid of how it looks from the outside!
author: christy w.

description: Good bbq items. The staff is really kind.
author: Katherine C.

description:
I agree that their BBQ pork is quite delicious but it's NOT worth $10.00  per pound! Other places in San Francisco are selling the same for $5.50 per pound! In addition, after the shop changed hands, they only use (headless) frozen chicken not the fresh ones that are more favorful and can be found at other stores. Seems the new management just want to make lots of money quickly in anyway possible including ripping off loyal customers. Did anyone else notice that their roasted duck ($12.50 each) are much smaller than the ones found at the other stores?
I don't shop at this store anymore...next time I feel like some good pork, duck or chicken I would go to Noriega or Irving! I can get the same or something better at a much better price and that really matters in today's economy where every dollar counts!
author: D L.

description: I've been frequenting this place on and off for some 4 months now. I quickly grew fond of the fast, friendly service and of course the Roasted Duck over Rice. Unfortunately, the quality of food and service have been declining from visit to visit. The duck ended up being fatter, having less meat, whilst chiefly consisting out of abnormally sized bones. I've seen a lot of ducks in my life, but none that would resemble such a shape, therefore I presume that these aren't naturally bred ducks, but the factory farming kind of poor quality. Of course, the duck's quality has never been A+++, but as aforementioned, the nice atmosphere and the well-used condiments made up for the poor meat quality. It's good street food, but it's just that "street food". Hong Kong version of shabby Hamburgers and Hot dogs... don't expect anything too fancy
author: Roger W.

description: This place is the mad notes for rice plates. You won't find a better scrambled egg and beef over rice anywhere. They also make a chow fun that will make you want to kiss your enemies. They offer both the dry and gravy sporting varieties.
author: riz n.

description: my husband found a *bug* in his chow-fun.  nuff said.
author: elaine i.

description: I'm giving 3 stars for the price and also the BBQ meats are normally good.  However recently i tried the preserve egg and pork jook and asked for an extra egg.  When I got it, I stirred the jook and could swear the amount of eggs seemed like the regular portion.  I questioned the waitress and she said they added the egg.  Next time I will ask for the egg on the side.  The other problem with the jook it was really watered down and almost taste like soup.  I would suggest you stay away from the jook dishes!!
author: Wally W.

description:
I love this place.  I've been coming here  for 3 years and it has never ever disapponted me. This little place has the absolute best wonton noodle on the west side of the city.  

Their potstickers are pretty darn tasty and plump.
author: kenny l.

description: Living a couple of block away this place is a godsend when I'm craving roast duck. They have good basic Chinese foods - wonton, HK style chow mein and fun. I think service has gotten friendlier since the mean old owner lady sold it, and from what I understand to a couple of employees.
author: Sheena L.

description:
Agreeing with the roast duck/pig comments everyone makes, but wanted to mention that the wontons and fish balls are also quite good.

It's totally a hole in the wall, but it's reasonably cheap and the food is quite good.  I don't think I've ever been dissapointed.
author: josh w.

description: My husband and I get take-out here at least once a week. Their duck and bbq pork rice plates are so hearty and delicious. And we always order soup - my favorite is the duck noodle soup or chicken juk. Hubby loves the Westlake minced beef soup.
author: Zoe S.

description: I have only been here once and probably will not go back.  The price was right and the service fast, but the food I ordered was pretty gross.  I was so hungry I was ready to gnaw my hands off, but the Sweet and Sour Chicken was so bad I just ended up eating some of the rice and then a Twix bar so I wouldn't pass out from hunger.
author: Dave O.

description:
Great comfort food! I've been going to Win's for over 10 years and I can't help but order the wonton soup every time. It has great flavor and lots of shrimp. When I go to Win's the only decision I need to make is whether or not I want to add chashu or baby bok choy to my wonton soup. But if I am really hungry I usually add noodles and go with wonton mein. My boyfriend on the other hand always orders the chashu dofu. The roast duck is also a very popular takeout item. 

* Win's was open on Christmas day in 2007. I ordered take out on my way back to San Francisco.
author: Akemi F.

description: just found another roast duck spot.  hello angina.
author: J M.

description: Great won ton mein at a decent and affordable price. Their barbecue items are just as good ie roast duck and the char seiw.
author: p a.

description: I live in Oakland but would come to Win's at least once every three weeks for my Peking duck. I love the flavor of the ducks here and how it melts in your mouth!
author: Lynne O.

description: This Chinese restaurant is 'A-OK'. I live two blocks away and sometimes come here when I have nothing to eat at home. Their roast duck and squid is good. I specially love the squid. If you eat squid, you should definitely try it! Sometimes my parents would come by here and get the squid as an extra dish for dinner. My whole family loves it!!  I haven't been here for anything else for awhile, but they have a huge selection and pretty cheap. Overall, not a bad place to go for a fast cheap chinese food. Definitely not the best but good enough for a neighborhood restaurant. It would be better if the place is cleaner and brighter.
author: Jane K.

description: Great place to get fast good Chinese food.  Pretty standard Chinese food hole in the wall.  If you get the standard beef chow fun or their porridge (jook) then you are safe.  I've never had their deli items but my parents which are older always said their roast pork is the best.  Service is ok if you don't speak Chinese and if you do, then service is better.  Don't expect much from the hole in the wall but for a quick meal, it's good.  Parking is limited because everyone wants to park in front.  Plenty of parking if you are willing to walk.
author: C T.

description: quick, cheap, and friendly. what more do you want from a neighborhood family owned shop? the food, to me, is only slightly better than "okay", but it is one of the better places to eat this side of sunset blvd. i must say, roast duck does get pretty gross without anything else to eat, so remember to order your rice.
author: Ben T.

description: good chinese food for lunch and dinner!!! live very close there and always get food from there!! prices are reasonable and service is good.. variety of food to choose from...
author: Lily T.

description: this place has been around, more miss than hit; alas new owners and the go to for bbq items in the sunset/parkside area, sit down was not bad, incredibly fair prices for what you get, stay away from the standard stuff, like chow this and that; and go for sauteed items and even though mom isnt always there to do it, they can!
author: tim y.

description: best thing ever is their wonton soup. you just cant go wrong with their wonton soup and if you can handle just a bit more you could add noodles with it. i think its less than $4 for wonton soup and maybe $5 with noodles. the place is kind of old looking but if youre hungry and dont want anything fancy this place gives good portions like other simple old traditional chinese places.
author: melanie t.

description: Win's taken a nose dive.  Varooom.  Walked in on a Friday PM at 5 PM, you'd think you walked into a ghost town.  Where were the people?  Only 1 couple dining.  I used to have to wait in line for take-out or a table at that hour.  Me thinks...bad economy?  Yes, they raised their prices but nothing drastic and definitely not as outrageous as Koi Palace.  A pound of roast pork was $8 and 1/2 duck about $6.   According to a previous reviewer, the place was sold.  Didn't recognize the dude behind the cash register or the butcher behind the glass.  But, I got my roast pork and roast duck in a jiffy.  The duck was fatty but still tasty.  The roast pork skin was crunchy but didn't have the flavor it used to.  I was disappointed, it wasn't the same which can happen when ownership changes.  We'll have to decide on another visit when we do the usual take-out food like chow mein to see how much of a drop in the quality of the food has occurred since the changes.
author: Ry T.

description: i love win's.  aside from the duck and ribs, the dumplings are amazing.  everything is fresh and the people are really nice.  its cheap and good, never a disappointment.  i love the snow peas and garlic as a side, and the dumplings in broth are delectable.
author: colin b.

description: I come here mainly for their duck and roast pork.  I know that that place across the street from safeway on noriega st. is even more popular for their ducks, but I prefer coming to Win's because I think it taste much better and they don't try to rip you off on the roast pork!  (you know how when you buy roast pork at some other place, they would make you pay for an extra piece)  Usually when I get my duck and pork from win's, the skin is still nice and crispy when I get back home.  I also like the soy sauce that comes with it.  It's so yummy when you dip the duck and pork in the sauce and eat it with a bowl of hot steamy rice.  Yum!!!
author: Katniss B.

description: Good chinese food, fast friendly service, big portions, and good prices. Try it, you won't regret it.
author: jon p.
